Cross reference- General penalty for violation of offenses, § 1-15; municipal court, § 2-191 et seq. 
State Law reference- Colorado Criminal Code, C.R.S. 18-1-101 et seq. 

Sec. 12-1. - Attempting, conspiring or inducing another to commit unlawful act. 
    It shall be unlawful to attempt to commit, conspire to commit or aid or abet in the commission of any act declared unlawful by this Code or any other ordinance of the city, whether committed individually or in connection with one (1) or more persons, as a principal, agent or accessory. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to falsely, fraudulently, forcibly or willfully induce, cause, coerce, require, permit or direct another to violate this Code or any other ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2-1989, § 19-40, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 12-2. - False reporting to authorities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Make or cause to be made a verbal, written, electronic or telephonic report to law enforcement authorities or other city authorities of or pertaining to a violation of a city ordinance, medical emergency, fire, disaster, criminal offense, or other incident within the authorities' official concern, knowing the report is false; 
(2)  Cause a telephone transmission to the E911 emergency number, knowing that no emergency exists and with intent to annoy, harass, or interfere with the emergency service systems; or 
(3)  Provide false verbal, written or printed information regarding such person's or other persons' identification to any police officer or any person duly appointed to serve as a special or extra officer when such identification information is lawfully requested by any such officer in the performance of his/her duty. 
(Ord. No. 2-1989, § 19-23, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89; Ord. No. 9-1994, 6-14-94, eff. 6-24-94) 
State Law reference- False reporting to authorities, C.R.S. 18-8-111. 
Sec. 12-3. - Obstructing or resisting police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly and willfully obstruct, resist, interfere with or oppose any police officer or person duly authorized to serve with or assist any police officer or any person duly appointed to serve as a special or extra officer, when such officer is engaged in the performance of his duties. 
(Code 1961, § 19-24) 
Cross reference- Police department, § 2-136 et seq. 
Sec. 12-4. - Refusal to comply with lawful order of police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly and willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction, including an order or direction to provide verbal, written or printed information regarding such person's or other persons' identification, of any police officer or any person duly appointed to serve as a special or extra officer, when such officer is engaged in the performance of his duties. 
(Ord. No. 28-1987, § 19-25, 12-8-87, eff. 12-21-87; Ord. No. 9-1994, 6-14-94, eff. 6-24-94) 
Sec. 12-5. - Escape from custody of police officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to escape from the custody of a police officer or, after being commanded by a police officer otherwise, to rescue another from the custody of a police officer or from the custody of any person aiding a police officer. The provisions of this section shall not apply whenever the escapee is being held for or charged with any felony or misdemeanor under state statute. 
(Ord. No. 2-1989, § 19-26, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 12-6. - Giving false fire alarm. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully give or make or cause to be given or made a false alarm of fire. 
(Code 1961, § 19-10) 
Cross reference- Fire protection and prevention, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 12-7. - Disturbing the peace. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb or to tend to disturb the peace of others by violent, tumultuous, offensive or obstreperous conduct, by loud or unusual noises, by unseemly, profane, obscene or offensive language calculated to provoke a breach of the peace, or by assaulting, striking or fighting another, or for any person to permit any such conduct in any house or upon any premises owned or possessed by him or under his management or control, when within his power to prevent, so that others in the vicinity are or may be disturbed thereby. Obstreperous conduct shall be defined as, but not limited to, violations of C.R.S. § 18-9-111, as amended. Tumultuous shall be defined as, but not limited to, violations of C.R.S. § 18-9-106, as amended. 
(Code 1961, § 19-8; Ord. No. 22-1997, 5-13-97, eff. 5-23-97; Ord. No. 8-2001, 4-10-01, eff. 4-20-01) 
Cross reference- Noise, § 11-51 et seq. 
Sec. 12-8. - Discharge of firearms, other explosive devices, and use of bows and crossbows. 
    Except as authorized by state statute, no person shall, within the city or within public parks belonging to the city, fire or discharge any cannon, gun, pistol, firearm, fireworks, except those defined as permissible in C.R.S. § 12-28-101(8), or air, spring or pellet gun of any description, or shoot arrows from any bow, crossbow or similar device, without permission in writing from the chief of police. Such permission shall limit the time and place of firing, for such purposes as dispersal of starlings, shooting of wells, pest control, and other similar uses. For firing on regularly maintained firing ranges, permission shall be limited to certain circumstances prescribed by the chief of police for safety and protection of persons and property. Such limitations may include, but are not limited to, the size and location of the range, the times during the day when the range may be operated, requirements that persons of certain qualifications, to be determined solely in the discretion of the chief of police, be present at all times when persons are firing on the range, a requirement that certain specified safety rules be followed, and a limitation of the use of firearms by persons under a specified age unless accompanied by an adult. Any person obtaining a permit under this section shall be on notice that he assumes the risk for the death of or injury to any person or damage to any property resulting either directly or indirectly from the intentional, reckless, negligent or accidental discharge of any gun. The chief of police and the city will not be liable for any damages which may result from granting a permit. 
(Code 1961, § 19-11; Ord. No. 23-1997, 5-13-97, eff. 5-23-97; Ord. No. 8-2001, 4-10-01, eff. 4-20-01) 
Cross reference- Discharge of firearms or dangerous missiles prohibited in any parks or recreation areas owned or leased by the city, § 13-63. 
Sec. 12-9. - Throwing stones or missiles. 
    No person shall throw any stone or other missile upon or at any person within the city. 
(Code 1961, § 19-32) 
Sec. 12-10. - Carrying concealed weapon. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not a peace officer, level I or Ia, or a peace officer, level II, while on duty, to carry concealed upon his person any dangerous or illegal weapon as defined by C.R.S. title 18, article 12, as may be amended from time to time, except that it shall be an affirmative defense that the person carrying a concealed weapon was: 
(1)  A person in his own dwelling or place of business, or on property owned or under his control at the time of the act of carrying; 
(2)  A person in a private automobile or other private means of conveyance who carries a weapon for lawful protection for his or another person or property while traveling; or 
(3)  A person who, prior to the time of carrying a concealed weapon, has been issued a written permit pursuant to C.R.S. section 18-12-105.1, as may be amended from time to time, to carry the weapon by the chief of police of a city, or city and county, or the sheriff of a county. 
(Code 1961, § 19-36; Ord. No. 8-1997, 3-11-97, eff. 3-21-97) 
Sec. 12-10.5. - Firearms prohibited in city buildings and other specific locations where posted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except a law enforcement officer, to carry any firearm within any building owned or leased by the city or any department or agency thereof whenever signs are posted at the public entrances of such a building informing persons that the carrying of firearms is prohibited in the building. For purposes of this section, officers of the Sterling Municipal Court in possession of a valid Colorado permit to carry concealed handguns shall be deemed law enforcement officers. 
(b)  Any officer, employee, agent or agency of the city responsible for the management of any real property owned or leased by the city is hereby authorized to prohibit, by rule, the carrying of firearms within any specific area under the jurisdiction of said officer, employee, agent or agency. Any such rule shall provide for the posting of signs at the public entrances to any specific area in which the carrying of firearms is prohibited informing the public of such prohibition. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except a law enforcement officer, to carry any firearm within any specific area owned or leased by the city or any department or agency thereof whenever the carrying of firearms in the specific area has been prohibited by rule as provided in subsection (b) of this section, and signs are posted at the public entrances of the specific area informing persons that the carrying of firearms is prohibited in the specific area. 
(d)  Nothing herein shall be deemed to affect or impair in any way the authority of any public or private property owner other than the city to prohibit the carrying of firearms into or upon other public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 20-2003, 9-23-03, eff. 10-2-03; Ord. No. 22-2009, 9-8-09, eff. 9-18-09) 
Sec. 12-11. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any child under the age of sixteen (16) years to loaf, loiter or be in any public street, alley or other public place within the city, on foot or in a conveyance of any nature, between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., unless accompanied by a parent or guardian or adult member of his family or other reputable adult person. 
(b)  Every parent, guardian or other person having the legal care, custody or control of any person under the age of sixteen (16) years who allows or permits such person to violate any provision of subsection (a) of this section is guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1961, §§ 19-20, 19-21) 
Sec. 12-12. - Possession of marijuana and drug paraphernalia. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Drug paraphernalia means all equipment, products, and materials of any kind which are used, intended for use, or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance in violation of the laws of this state. "Drug paraphernalia" includes, but is not limited to: 
a.  Testing equipment used, intended for use, or designed for use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness, or purity of controlled substances under circumstances in violation of the laws of this state; 
b.  Scales and balances used, intended for use, or designed for use in weighing or measuring controlled substances; 
c.  Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use, or designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from or in otherwise cleaning or refining marijuana; 
d.  Blenders, bowls, containers, spoons, and mixing devices used, intended for use, or designed for use in compounding controlled substances; 
e.  Capsules, balloons, envelopes, and other containers used, intended for use, or designed for use in packaging small quantities of controlled substances; 
f.  Containers and other objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in storing or concealing controlled substances; or 
g.  Objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marijuana, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into the human body, such as: 
1.  Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or punctured metal bowls; 
2.  Water pipes; 
3.  Carburetion tubes and devices; 
4.  Smoking and carburetion masks; 
5.  Roach clips, meaning objects used to hold burning material, such as a marijuana cigarette that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand; 
6.  Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials; 
7.  Chamber pipes; 
8.  Carburetor pipes; 
9.  Electric pipes; 
10.  Air-driven pipes; 
11.  Chillums; 
12.  Bongs; or 
13.  Ice pipes or chillers. 
(2)  Marihuana or marijuana means all parts of the plant Cannabis sativa L., whether growing or not, the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of the plant, and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the plant, its seeds, or its resin. It does not include fiber produced from the stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of the plant, or sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination if these items exist apart from any other item defined as "marihuana" in this subsection (a). "Marihuana" does not include marihuana concentrate as defined in subsection (2) of this section. 
(3)  Marihuana concentrate means hashish, tetrahydrocannabinols, or any alkaloid, salt, derivative, preparation, compound, or mixture, whether natural or synthesized, of tetrahydrocannabinols. 
(b)  Prohibitions. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess marijuana. 
(2)  Any charges brought against an individual for possession of greater than one (1) ounce of marijuana, or for marijuana concentrate, shall not be within the jurisdiction of the municipal court by virtue of this section, but shall be prosecuted pursuant to state statute. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess drug paraphernalia if he knows or reasonably should know that the drug paraphernalia could be used under circumstances in violation of the laws of the city and State of Colorado. In determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia, the court, in its discretion, may consider, in addition to all other relevant factors, the following: 
a.  Statements by an owner or by anyone in control of the object concerning its use; 
b.  The proximity of the object to controlled substances; 
c.  The existence of any residue of controlled substances on the object; 
d.  Expert testimony concerning its use. 
(Ord. No. 19-1998, 7-14-98, eff. 7-24-98; Ord. No. 9-1999, 5-25-99, eff. 6-4-99) 
Sec. 12-13. - Trespassing. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or remain upon the property, real or personal, of another without the consent of the owner of the property, occupant of the property, or the agent or servant of the owner or occupant of such property. Such entry without consent shall be a violation of this section, whether or not the person so unlawfully entering such property is requested to remove himself immediately from the property. When a person enters onto property after having received written notification not to do so, it shall be prima facie evidence that the entry was without consent. 
(b)  It shall further be unlawful for a person who has entered the property, real or personal, of another with the consent of the owner to fail or refuse to remove himself immediately from the property when requested to leave by the owner or occupant of the property or the agent or servant of the owner or occupant. Failure to do so shall be a violation of this section. 
(Code 1961, § 19-38; Ord. No. 17-1987, § 19-38, 9-8-87, eff. 9-21-87; Ord. No. 29-1995, 11-28-95, eff. 12-8-95) 
Sec. 12-14. - Theft. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit a theft. A person commits a theft when he knowingly obtains or exercises control over any thing belonging to another where the aggregate value is less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), without authorization, or by threat or deception, and: 
(1)  Intends to deprive the other person permanently of the use or benefit of the thing of value; 
(2)  Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the thing of value in such manner as to deprive the other person permanently of its use or benefit; 
(3)  Uses, conceals or abandons the thing of value, intending that such use, concealment or abandonment will deprive the other person permanently of its use and benefit; or 
(4)  Demands any consideration to which he is not legally entitled as a condition of restoring the thing of value to the other person. 
(b)  If any person willfully conceals unpurchased goods, wares or merchandise owned and held by and offered or displayed for sale by any store or other mercantile establishment, whether the concealment is on his person or otherwise and whether on or off the premises of the store or mercantile establishment, such concealment constitutes prima facie evidence that the person intended to commit the crime of theft. 
(c)  Evidence that any person willfully obtains any food, drink, goods, wares, merchandise, services or lodging under false pretenses; enters any public place and calls for refreshments or other articles and receives and refuses to pay for such articles; departs without paying for or satisfying the person from whom he received food, drink, goods, wares, merchandise, services or lodging; or, having lawfully obtained possession for temporary use of personal property of another which is available only for hire, knowingly fails to reveal the whereabouts of or to return such property to the owner thereof or his representative or to the person from whom he has received it within seventy-two (72) hours after the time at which he agreed to return it, shall constitute prima facie evidence that the person intended to commit the crime of theft. The standard for prima facie evidence regarding intent to commit the crime of theft for rental property with a value less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be the failure to return such property after a period of thirty (30) days has elapsed since the person renting such property was required to return same to the property owner. Rental property with a value of less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be the only exception to the seventy-two-hour rule specified within this paragraph (c). 
(Code 1961, §§ 19-39, 19-40; Ord. No. 18-1987, §§ 19-39, 19-40, 9-8-87, eff. 9-21-87; Ord. No. 2-1989, § 19-39, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89; Ord. No. 24-1992, 7-28-92, eff. 8-10-92; Ord. No. 18-1995, 9-12-95, eff. 9-22-95; Ord. No. 28-1998, 8-11-98, eff. 8-21-98; Ord. No. 2-2008, 2-26-08, eff. 3-7-08) 
Sec. 12-15. - Injuring or defacing property generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deface or injure any property not his own, whether public or private. 
(Code 1961, § 19-19) 
Sec. 12-16. - Injuring trees or flowers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, injure, mark or deface any tree or flower planted for ornament or shade within the city. This section shall not be deemed to apply to any person cutting trees or flowers upon their own property or upon the property of another with the permission of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1961, § 19-33) 
Cross reference- Vegetation, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 12-17. - Posting of handbills without property owner's consent. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to post, paste, paint, mark, nail or otherwise fasten or append any advertisement, handbill, poster or notice of any kind upon any curbstone, sidewalk, tree, utility pole, or hydrant, or upon any billboard, wall, door, gate or fence within the city, without the written consent of the owner. 
(b)  In addition to the penalty provided for in section 1-15, any person who violates this section shall be adjudged to pay the costs of tearing down or obliterating any notice, advertisement, handbill or poster put up contrary to the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1961, § 3-9) 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and business regulations, Ch. 9; nuisances, Ch. 11; trees and other plantings, § 22-26 et seq. 
Sec. 12-18. - Making unauthorized connection to cable television system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any unauthorized connection, whether physically, electrically, acoustically, inductively or otherwise, with any part of a company's CATV system, for the purpose of enabling anyone to receive any television signal, radio signal, picture, sound, or other transmission, without payment to the company. 
(Code 1961, § 19-6.2) 
State Law reference- Theft of cable television service, C.R.S. 18-4-701 et seq. 
Cross reference- Cable communications system, Ch. 5.5. 
Sec. 12-19. - Tampering with cable television facilities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without the consent of the owner, to willfully tamper with, remove or injure any cables, wires or equipment of a company's CATV system used for distribution of television signals, radio signals, pictures, sound or other transmission. 
(Code 1961, § 19-6.3) 
Cross reference- Cable communications system, Ch. 5.5. 
Sec. 12-20. - Public indecency. 
    Any person who performs any of the following in a public place or where the conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by members of the public commits public indecency: 
(1)  An act of sexual intercourse; 
(2)  An act of deviant sexual intercourse; 
(3)  A lewd exposure of the body done with intent to arouse or to satisfy the sexual desire to any person; or 
(4)  A lewd fondling or caress of the body of another person. 
(Code 1961, § 19-16) 
Sec. 12-21. - Indecent exposure. 
    A person commits indecent exposure if he knowingly exposes his genitals to the view of any person under circumstances in which such conduct is likely to cause affront or alarm to the other person. Such behavior is declared to be unlawful. 
(Code 1961, § 19-17) 
Cross reference- Nudity prohibited in public parks and recreation areas, § 13-62. 
Sec. 12-22. - Furnishing tobacco products to minors; sale of tobacco products in vending machines. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Tobacco products means cigars, cheroots, stogies, periques, granulated, plug cut, crimp cut, ready rubbed, and other smoking tobacco, snuff, snuff flour, cavendish, plus and twist tobacco, fine-cut and other chewing tobaccos, shorts, refuse scraps, clippings, cuttings and sweepings of tobacco and other kinds and forms of tobacco, prepared in such manner as to be suitable for chewing or for smoking in a pipe or otherwise, or for both chewing and smoking. 
    Smokeless tobacco product means any finely cut, ground, powered, or leaf tobacco that is intended to be placed in the oral cavity or nasal passage, including but not limited to snuff and chewing tobacco. 
(b)  Prohibitions. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly furnish to any person who is under eighteen (18) years of age by gift, sale or any other means, any cigarettes or tobacco products, as defined in subsection (a) above. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is under eighteen (18) years of age to purchase any cigarettes or tobacco products, as defined in subsection (a) above. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person under eighteen (18) years of age to have in such persons' possession any cigarettes or tobacco products, as defined in subsection (a) above. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer to sell any smokeless tobacco product by use of a vending machine or other coin-operated machine. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell any cigarettes or tobacco products, other than a smokeless tobacco product, by use of a vending machine or any other coin-operated machine which does not display the following warning sign: 
WARNING 
IT IS ILLEGAL FOR ANY PERSON UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF AGE TO PURCHASE CIGARETTES AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS AND, UPON CONVICTION, A FINE MAY BE IMPOSED. 
The warning sign shall be displayed in a prominent place on such machine at all times and shall have a minimum height of three (3) inches and a width of six (6) inches. 
(c)  A violation of the provisions of subsection (b)(5) above shall not constitute a violation of any other provisions of this section. 
(Ord. of 6-1990, 6-26-90, eff. 6-29-90) 
Sec. 12-23. - Penalty. 
    The penalty for a violation of this chapter shall be the same as that specifically provided in section 2-243, except that where the person charged is under the age of eighteen (18) years, there shall be no jail sentence imposed as a penalty and such other restrictions on the penalty as may be set forth in section 1-15. In the event that a violation occurs pursuant to this section and a specific penalty is not set forth in section 2-243, the penalty shall be at the court's discretion. It shall, however, still be subject to section 1-15. 
(Ord. No. 41-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Chapter 13 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Department of parks, library and recreation §§ 4-6, 9-1 et seq.; parks, library and recreation board, § 9-4. 
Cross reference- Parks, library and recreation department, § 2-166; open containers of alcoholic beverages prohibited on streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public ways or public places and in any vehicle, § 3-12; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; park and recreation areas in subdivisions, § 18-108. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board means the board of the department of parks, library and recreation of the city, as constituted by article IX of the charter. 
    City manager means the city manager of the city or his designee. 
    Department means the department of parks, library and recreation of the city. 
    Director means the director of the department of parks, library and recreation of the city or the director's designee. 
    Group activities means the use of a specific area for organized group use or activity, including but not limited to company picnics, athletic events, theatrical events, group meetings and similar activities, including scheduled use of park areas, pavilions, athletic fields and buildings. 
    Park means a park, reservation, playground, campsite, recreation area or other area owned by or leased to the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-3, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-2. - Applicability of chapter. 
    This chapter shall apply throughout all parks and recreational areas owned by or leased to the city, both within and without the municipal limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-1, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-3. - Adoption and enforcement of rules and regulations. 
    The director of the department shall have the responsibility to develop rules and regulations relating to properties and related facilities under the supervision of the department, whether inside or outside the city, and for the preservation of order, safety and decency therein. On recommendation of the city manager, the board shall have power to adopt all such needed rules and regulations. For the purpose of enforcing such rules and regulations, all such properties shall be under the police jurisdiction of the city. Any member of the police force of the city or park employee appointed as a special policeman shall have power to arrest without warrant, on all such properties, any person who has violated any such rule or regulation or committed any offense therein. All violations occurring in the presence of city employees may be processed upon the civilian complaint by such city employee to the police department. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-3, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-4. - Authority to seize property. 
    Law enforcement officials shall be empowered to seize and confiscate any property, thing or device in a park or recreation facility owned by or leased to the city, which property, thing or device is used in violation of any provision of this chapter or in violation of the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to this chapter and which is related to charges brought pursuant to violations of this chapter or violations of rules and regulations promulgated in accordance with this chapter. Such seizure and confiscation shall be in accord with general federal and state seizure and confiscation law. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-29, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-5. - Obedience to orders of park superintendents and employees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disobey the lawful or reasonable order of a park superintendent or park employee. Any person who has been ordered to leave a park or recreation facility and who fails to leave or reenters after leaving shall be considered trespassing. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-6, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-6. - Penalty. 
    The penalty for a violation of this chapter shall be the same as that specifically provided in section 2-243, except that where the person charged is under the age of eighteen (18) years, there shall be no jail sentence imposed as a penalty and such other restrictions on the penalty as may be set forth in section 1-15. In the event that a violation occurs pursuant to this section and a specific penalty is not set forth in section 2-243, the penalty shall be at the court's discretion. It shall, however, still be subject to section 1-15. 
(Ord. No. 42-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 42-1995, adopted December 12, 1995, effective December 22, 1995, amended Chapter 13 by adding a new Art. IV. For purposes of classification, such new provisions were included herein as § 13-6 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 13-7-13-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT FOR GROUP OR NONRECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES 

Sec. 13-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Permit means a permit for group or recreational activities required pursuant to this article. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-22. - Permit required. 
    Permits must be obtained from the director for the following: 
(1)  Any group activity involving fifty (50) or more persons who desire a specific area of any park or recreation facility of the city. 
(2)  Use by any person engaging in any nonrecreational activity in a park or recreation facility. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-4(a), 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-23. - Authority to issue permits. 
    Permits may only be issued by the director. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-4, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-24. - Contents of application. 
    The permit application shall include: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The name and address of the person sponsoring the activity, if any. 
(3)  The days and hours for which the permit is desired. 
(4)  The park or portion thereof for which the permit is desired. 
(5)  An estimate of the anticipated attendance, if applicable. 
(6)  The nature and duration of the proposed activities. 
(7)  Any other information which the director finds reasonably necessary for fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-4(b), 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-25. - Granting; denial. 
(a)  The director of the department shall have the responsibility to develop rules and regulations for obtaining a permit to engage in group or nonrecreational activities. On recommendation of the city manager, the board shall have power to adopt such needed rules and regulations. In reviewing permit applications and in issuing or denying a permit, the director shall base a determination on: 
(1)  The fact that the primary purpose of parks is to provide areas for the residents of the city and the general public to engage in recreational activities and temporarily exchange the urban environment for a more natural one; and 
(2)  The necessity of protecting and preserving the city's parks for recreational use by the citizens of the city and the general public. 
(b)  The director shall issue a permit when he finds that: 
(1)  The proposed specific activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general public enjoyment of the parks and is consistent with the primary purpose of the parks; 
(2)  The proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of the public health, welfare, safety and recreation; 
(3)  The proposed activity or use is not reasonably anticipated to incite violence, crime, violation of municipal ordinances or disorderly conduct; 
(4)  The proposed activity will not entail unusual, extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the city; 
(5)  The proposed activity will not violate any conditions of the city's ownership, occupancy or lease of the park; 
(6)  The proposed activity will not unreasonably endanger wildlife in the park or impact the environment detrimentally; and 
(7)  The desired facilities have not been previously requested for use at the day and hour requested in the application. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-4(c), 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-26. - Response to applicant; review by city manager. 
    The director shall respond in writing to a written permit application within two (2) weeks after receipt of all information necessary to make a determination. All permits shall be reviewed by the city manager in his capacity as chief executive officer, and he may, in such instances as he deems appropriate, order the director to issue the permit subject to findings that the director is required to establish under subsection 13-25(b) and section 13-27, or he may deny the permit. Upon determination by the city manager, the director shall notify the applicant in writing whether the permit has been granted or denied and, if denied, of the reasons for the denial. If the permit was denied by the city manager after being granted by the director, the city manager shall give such reasons for denial. Such action by the city manager shall be taken within ten (10) days from the date the director submits the matter to the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-4(f), 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-27. - Contents of permit; bond. 
    All permits issued shall describe both the park area and the date and time when the permit is valid, the nature of the activity permitted, and such reasonable restrictions or requirements as deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the standards for issuance set forth in subsection 13-25(b). The permittee shall post a bond or guarantee in a form acceptable to the director in an amount sufficient to ensure restoration of the park to its prior condition or to remedy any unacceptable impact upon the environment or wildlife. The permit shall also state (unless signed by the person to whom the permit is issued), that by acceptance and use of the permit the permittee agrees to indemnify and save and hold harmless the city for any liability the city may incur as a result of such negligence. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-4(d), 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-28. - Cancellation. 
    The director shall have the power and authority to cancel any permit for any violation of the conditions of the permit, as well as for any violation of the rules and regulations governing use of the city parks. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-4(e), 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-29. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make false statements or give false information in connection with an application for a permit. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage or prepare to engage in any group or nonrecreational activity in any park or recreation area owned by or leased to the city except as authorized by a written permit issued by the director. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-19(a), (b), 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-30. - Display of permit. 
    Any person engaging in group or nonrecreational activities within the park pursuant to permit must carry the permit in his possession while engaging in such activities, and must produce it upon the demand of the director, a park superintendent or employee, or an agent of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-19(b), 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Secs. 13-31-13-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - USE OF PARKS AND RECREATION AREAS 

Sec. 13-46. - Hours of use. 
(a)  Parks shall be open during designated hours. It shall be unlawful to enter or be in any park when it has been declared closed to the public by the director. Parks shall normally be open daily during the hours posted on signs located at each entrance to the park area, except for activities and events sponsored or authorized by the director. If the park is not posted with signs identifying specific open or closed hours, the park shall be closed daily in accordance with rules and regulations establishing opening and closing hours for all parks or for each park separately. The director, however, may declare any park closed at any time and for any interval of time as necessary to protect the public health, welfare and safety. Such declaration, when posted, shall have the same effect as a rule or regulation approved by the board. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to occupy a parking site with a motorized vehicle between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., unless in the designated camping area at Pioneer Park. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-5, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-47. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful to store or consume any malt, vinous or spirituous liquor as defined in C.R.S. 12-47-101 et seq., the state Liquor Code or any fermented malt beverage as defined in C.R.S. 12-46-101 et seq., the state Beer Code, in any park or recreation area owned by or leased to the city, except at the Overland Trail Museum under a specifically regulated permitting process as adopted by the parks, library and recreation board, as recommended by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-7, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89; Ord. No. 2-2015, 3-24-15, eff. 4-3-15) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 13-48. - Open fires. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to allow open fires on park lands, except in designated grills at Pioneer Park. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to allow a fire to burn in a careless manner, to leave any fire unattended, or to fail to extinguish completely any fire on park lands. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-8, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 13-49. - Commercial activity. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct any commercial activity on park lands or sell or offer for sale any service, product or activity for which a fee is charged, except when such activity is authorized in writing by the director. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-9, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and business regulations, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 13-50. - Motor vehicles generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or park a motor vehicle within any park of the city except in designated areas or as authorized by signs, the order of the director, a park superintendent or employees or an agent of the police or fire department. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave a motor vehicle within any park owned by or leased to the city when it has been declared closed to the public by the director, unless the motor vehicle is parked in a designated area. Parks shall normally be open daily during the hours posted on signs located at each entrance to the park area, except for activities and events sponsored by the director or authorized by the director. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of chapter 10 (pertaining to motor vehicles and traffic), in any park within the municipal limits of the city or other park outside the municipal limits of the city owned by or leased to the city. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-27, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10. 
Sec. 13-51. - Driving motorized vehicle on or in water body. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any motorized vehicle of any kind on any lake, stream or water area on park lands, whether such lake or stream is frozen or not, unless authorized by the director in writing. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-16, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10. 
Sec. 13-52. - Snowmobiles. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a snowmobile in any park, parkway or other recreational area owned by or leased to the city, unless authorized by permit. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-13, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10. 
Sec. 13-53. - Animals running at large. 
(a)  It is unlawful for the owner of any animal to permit the animal to run at large within any park or recreation facility owned by or leased to the city. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the definitions found in section 4-1 are applicable. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-26, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 13-54. - Defecation by animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any animal which has defecated in any park, parkway or recreational facility to fail to clean up and remove such excrement or feces. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-10, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 13-55. - Horse riding. 
    It shall be unlawful to ride a horse or other animal on park lands except upon an authorized bridle path or on other areas which are specifically designated by the director for such use. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-18, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 13-56. - Ice skating. 
    It shall be unlawful to ice skate on any water body supervised by the department or included in any park or recreation facility unless the specific area to be used is so posted or public announcement has been made by the director allowing such activity. When such areas are open for use, they are subject to such rules and regulations as shall be approved pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-11, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-57. - Sledding. 
    It shall be unlawful to sled within any park or recreation facility of the city, except in areas designated for such use. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-12, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-58. - Golfing. 
    No person shall drive, putt or in any other fashion play or practice golf or use golf balls or golf clubs in any area of any park or recreation facility owned by or leased to the city, except in areas set aside or posted for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-28, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-59. - Camping. 
    It shall be unlawful to camp within any park or recreation facility owned by or leased to the city, except in designated areas of Pioneer Park or as approved by the director. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-20, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-60. - Fishing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person on park lands to violate any of the provisions contained in chapter 1 of the Rules and Regulations of the Colorado Division of Wildlife, which is adopted by reference pursuant to C.R.S. title 31, article 16. Any violation of chapter 1 of the Rules and Regulations of the Colorado Division of Wildlife shall be a violation of this section and punishable as specified in section 1-15. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-14, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-61. - Trapping or hunting wildlife. 
    It shall be unlawful to place traps on park lands, except as authorized by permit, and it shall also be unlawful to possess, pursue, wound, take or acquire any deer, wildlife or wild birds. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-15, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-62. - Nudity. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person on park lands to appear or disrobe so as to expose or uncover his or her lower torso in such a manner as to expose the cleft of the buttocks or genital organs. It shall be unlawful for any female who is five (5) years or older to appear or disrobe in such a manner as to expose the areola. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-17, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Indecent exposure prohibited, § 12-21. 
Sec. 13-63. - Discharge of firearms or dangerous missiles. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge, fire or shoot any air gun, slingshot, pellet gun, blowgun, arrow, firearm or other projectile or projectile-launching device in any park or recreation facility owned by or leased to the city, except in designated areas. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-24, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Discharge of firearms or other explosives prohibited in the city, § 12-8. 
Sec. 13-64. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 27-1997, adopted May 27, 1997, effective June 6, 1997, repealed § 13-64 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to fireworks and derived from Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-25, adopted March 14, 1989, effective March 17, 1989. 
Sec. 13-65. - Destruction of public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly remove, destroy, mutilate, modify or deface any building, structure, water control device, fence, gate, notice, sign, survey or section marker, tree, shrub or other plant or vegetation or any other item of public property within any park or recreation facility owned by or leased to the city. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-21, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Sec. 13-66. - Littering. 
    It shall be unlawful to leave any garbage, trash, cans, bottles, papers or other refuse elsewhere within any park or recreation facility owned by or leased to the city other than in the receptacles provided therefor. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-22, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 11. 
Sec. 13-67. - Use of trash receptacles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use the receptacles provided for in section 13-66 for the purpose of depositing yard clippings or other garbage or trash generated on private property. Evidence such as envelopes, boxes, cartons, bills or any other documents with a person's name thereon found in such receptacle shall be prima facie evidence that that person deposited such items in the receptacle personally. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 19A-23, 3-14-89, eff. 3-17-89) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 11.

ARTICLE III. - RULES AND PROCEDURES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-71. - Personnel manual. 
    The personnel rules, policies, regulations and other administrative provisions are contained in a manual on file in the city clerk's office. 
Sec. 14-72. - Holidays. 
    The following days shall be official holidays of the city: 
(1)  New Year's Day, January 1. 
(2)  President's Day, third Monday in February. 
(3)  Memorial Day, last Monday in May. 
(4)  Independence Day, July 4. 
(5)  Labor Day, first Monday in September. 
(6)  Veterans' Day, November 11. 
(7)  Thanksgiving Day, fourth Thursday in November. 
(8)  First Friday after Thanksgiving Day. 
(9)  Christmas Day, December 25. 
(Ord. No. 19-1991, 10-22-91, eff. 1-1-92; Ord. No. 18-1994, 9-27-94, eff. 10-7-94) 
Sec. 14-73. - Disciplinary actions and appeal. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
    City manager means the city manager, or his or her designee in the event of a prolonged absence from work of the city manager. Disciplinary actions subject to the appeal process means disciplinary actions that are punitive in nature as follows: 
(1)  Suspension without pay. 
(2)  Demotion. 
(3)  Termination or dismissal. 
    Working day means the normal city hall administrative operating hours during the workweek (8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday). Days of city hall closure will not be counted as a working day under this section. 
(b)  City manager responsibility. The city manager shall be responsible for the development and implementation of a review process, through personnel policies, to review disciplinary actions not specifically addressed in this section. 
(c)  Authority to discipline employees. The department head of each department of the city may recommend the discipline of or termination of an employee. In the case of a division head with direct reporting responsibility to the city manager, the division head shall function as would a department head in the discipline or termination process. 
(d)  Appeal process of disciplinary actions. 
(1)  The appeal hearing is the opportunity for the employee to explain or present the employee's side of a disputed disciplinary action. The appeal hearing shall be informal in nature and therefore the formal rules of evidence will not be followed. 
(2)  An employee is offered the opportunity to request an appeal of a disciplinary action as listed in this section. An appeal shall be granted only after an employee has received notification from the employee's department head of the disciplinary action. After receipt of the department head notification, the employee must request the appeal. An appeal request shall be in writing, signed, and dated by the employee and delivered to the human resource office prior to 5:00 p.m. on the third working day after the employee's receipt of the departmental disciplinary notification. If an employee does not request an appeal within this time period, the opportunity to appeal is forfeited and the disciplinary action will become final. From the date of the departmental delivery of the notification of disciplinary action to the final determination of the disciplinary action by the city manager, the employee shall be placed on administrative leave (suspension with pay). 
(3)  The appeal hearing shall be held on or before the tenth working day following the receipt of the request for an appeal hearing. The employee requesting the appeal shall be informed of the date and time of the appeal meeting. Should an employee fail to appear on the established meeting date, the disciplinary action will become effective retroactively to the original delivery date of the notification of the disciplinary action by the department head requesting the disciplinary action. 
(4)  Information to be available to the city manager hearing the appeal shall include the disciplinary action notification, employment record of the employee requesting the appeal, the employee's request for appeal, and other documents pertaining directly to the disciplinary action. The purpose of the hearing is for the city manager to determine if the disciplinary action imposed is warranted and if the disciplinary action is appropriate for the alleged actions or behaviors of the employee. The findings of the city manager shall be made and distributed no later than 5:00 p.m. on the tenth working day following the appeal hearing. The city manager shall be afforded the discretion to conduct further investigations into the disciplinary action should the city manager deem it advisable and in the best interest of the city to do so. 
(5)  Any action taken by the city manager regarding the appealed disciplinary action shall be final. 
(6)  That this appeal process shall only apply to regular, nonintroductory, nonprobationary employees. 
(Code 1961, § 2-40; Ord. No. 3-1987, § 2-39, 3-10-87, eff. 3-23-87; Ord. No. 22-2007, 11-27-07, eff. 12-7-07; Ord. No. 23-2007, 1-8-08, eff. 1-18-08; Ord. No. 4-2018, 3-13-18, eff. 3-23-18) 
Sec. 14-74. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 22-2007, adopted November 27, 2007, effective December 7, 2007, deleted § 14-74, which pertained to hearing and derived from Ord. No. 19-1996, 4-23-96, eff. 5-3-96.

DIVISION 2. - CLASSIFIED SERVICE 

Sec. 14-91. - Citizenship. 
    Applicants for appointment or promotion in the classified service shall be citizens of the United States. 
(Code 1961, § 2-37; Ord. No. 3-1987, § 2-37, 3-10-87, eff. 3-23-87) 
Sec. 14-92. - Veterans preference. 
    Veterans shall receive a preference for appointments and promotions in the classified service in accord with article XII, section 15, of the state constitution. 
(Code 1961, § 2-35; Ord. No. 3-1987, § 2-35, 3-10-87, eff. 3-23-87) 
Sec. 14-93. - Examinations generally. 
(a)  Appointments and promotions for all police officers and firefighters shall be made according to the merit and fitness of the persons appointed or promoted, as ascertained by competitive testing. 
(b)  Appointments and promotions for all other personnel of the police and fire departments shall be made according to the merit and fitness of the persons appointed or promoted, as ascertained so far as practicable by competitive testing. 
(Code 1961, § 2-35; Ord. No. 3-1987, § 2-35, 3-10-87, eff. 3-25-87; Ord. No. 33-1999, 12-14-99, eff. 12-24-99; Ord. No. 4-2018, 3-13-18, eff. 3-23-18) 
Sec. 14-94. - Fraudulent practices in connection with examinations. 
    No person shall, with respect to an examination for the classified service, willfully or corruptly, by himself or in cooperation with one (1) or more persons: 
(1)  Defeat, deceive or obstruct any person in respect to his right of examination; 
(2)  Falsely mark, grade, estimate or report upon the examination or proper standing of any person examined under this division, or aid in so doing, or make any false representation concerning any person's examination or standing or concerning the person examined; 
(3)  Furnish to any person any special or secret information for the purpose of either improving or injuring the prospects or chances of any persons so examined or to be examined; or 
(4)  Impersonate another person or permit or aid another person to impersonate him in any application, examination or registration. 
(Code 1961, § 2-36; Ord. No. 3-1987, § 2-36, 3-10-87, eff. 3-25-87) 
Sec. 14-95. - Oath of police officers and firefighters. 
    Before entering upon the duties of office, every police officer and firefighter shall take and subscribe before the director of finance, and file with the director of finance, an oath or affirmation that he will support the Constitution of the United States and of the state, the laws of the state and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city and faithfully perform the duties of the office upon which he is about to enter. 
(Code 1961, § 2-38; Ord. No. 3-1987, § 2-38, 3-10-87, eff. 3-25-87) 
Secs. 14-96-14-115. - Reserved.

Sec. 14-131. - Participation of city. 
    Pursuant to C.R.S. 24-53-101 et seq., the city shall extend to its employees the basic protection provided by the old age and survivors insurance system in the Federal Social Security Act, except those employees that are covered under an approved state pension plan. 
(Code 1961, § 2-2) 
Sec. 14-132. - Contributions. 
(a)  The director of finance is hereby authorized to pay, in accordance with this article, from the funds of the city to the appropriate agency pursuant to state and federal law, contributions with respect to the wages of the employees of the city and contributions withheld from the wages of employees of the city as required by state and federal law. 
(b)  The director of finance is authorized to impose upon the employees of the city a contribution with respect to their wages and to deduct the amount of such contribution not exceeding the amount of tax imposed by the Federal Insurance Contributions Act, 26 U.S.C. 3101, for service constituting employment within the meaning of that act. 
(Code 1961, § 2-3) 
Chapter 15 - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Improvement districts, § 8-7; bonds, §§ 8-8-8-10. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; taxation and finance, Ch. 19; utilities, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Public improvements, C.R.S. 31-25-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 15-1995, adopted August 8, 1995, effective August 18, 1995, repealed §§ 15-1-15-5, 15-36-15-57, 15-81-15-103 in their entirety. Formerly, such sections pertained to general public improvements, administration and general procedure, and assessment and lien procedure and derived from §§ 16-1-16-18 and 16-30-16-60 of the 1961 Code, and from § 16-64 of Ord. No. 4-1987, adopted March 24, 1987, effective March 23, 1987. Ordinance No. 15-1995 also added new §§ 15-1-15-5 to read as herein set forth. 

Sec. 15-1. - Procedure under state statutes. 
    The city council may proceed under all applicable state statutes to initiate and finance local improvement districts or special or local improvement bonds. When local improvements are not financed by bonds, but are instead funded by the city, then pursuant to the home rule powers of the city, a special district may be created by the city council, pursuant to section 15-6. 
(Ord. No. 15-1995, 8-8-95, eff. 8-18-95; Ord. No. 37-1998, 9-8-98) 
Charter reference- Special or local improvements, § 8-8. 
Sec. 15-2. - General powers of council. 
    The city council shall have the power to contract for and make improvements and [to] local improvement districts. 
(Ord. No. 15-1995, 8-8-95, eff. 8-18-95) 
Sec. 15-3. - Award of contracts; recommendation by director of public works. 
    All contracts for public improvements shall be awarded by the city council after review for compliance with state and federal statutes and upon recommendation by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 15-1995, 8-8-95, eff. 8-18-95) 
Sec. 15-4. - Acquisition by independent contract or day labor. 
    Local improvements may be acquired by independent contract or by day labor under the supervision of the director of public works, and shall be in compliance with section 6-7 of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 15-1995, 8-8-95, eff. 8-18-95) 
Sec. 15-5. - Advertising for bids; bond of contractor. 
    Whenever local improvements are to be constructed by an independent contractor, the director of public works shall give public notice of this fact and call for bids for doing the work. All contractors shall provide performance bonds provided by surety which meets council approval. In the event of default by a contractor, the director of public works may re-let the remainder of the work without further ordinance and recover excess cost, if any, by suit on the original bond. Advertisements for bid will contain a provision allowing the city to reject any and all bids, and if all bids are rejected, additional advertisements for bid will not require the passage of another ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 15-1995, 8-8-95, eff. 8-18-95) 
Sec. 15-6. - City-funded special improvement districts. 
    When local improvements are not financed by bonds, but from the general fund of the city, pursuant to the home rule powers of the city, the city council may form a special improvement district for the purpose of repayment to the city of all funds used to finance the improvements. Any special improvement district formed by the city council and funded by the city shall first be initiated by petition requesting formation of the special district, and signed by fifty-one (51) percent of the landowners representing fifty-one (51) percent of the land located within the district. The city council may, if feasible, create the special improvement district, by ordinance, provided sufficient funds exist for the financing of the proposed improvements for which the special district will be formed. The ordinance shall specify the assessments to be made for repayment to the city, including, but not limited to, interest, if applied, and payment periods required. Upon final payment to the city, the special improvement district shall terminate. 
(Ord. No. 37-1998, 9-8-98) 
Secs. 15-7-15-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SPECIFIC IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 15-126. - Construction of sidewalks generally. 
(a)  In districts for the construction and reconstruction of sidewalks alone, or in combination with other improvements, the work shall include the necessary grading from curbline to lot line. The owner of any lot or tract to be assessed shall have the right to construct or reconstruct his own walks in conformity with the plans and specifications for the district, within thirty (30) days from the publication of the ordinance authorizing the improvement. Whenever sidewalks are ordered in combination with improvements other than grading sidewalk areas, a separate contract may be let for the construction and reconstruction of the sidewalks exclusive of the necessary grading. 
(b)  The whole cost of construction and reconstruction of sidewalks, including intersections and necessary grading and removal of obstructions, shall be assessed upon the lots or lands in front of which such improvements are made, as follows: the grading, removal of obstructions, intersections and all other general expenses, including cost of collection and interest, pro rata per front foot; new walks pro rata per front foot where constructed; and reconstructed walks upon each lot or piece of land where reconstructed according to the cost of reconstruction. 
(Code 1961, § 16-19) 
Sec. 15-127. - Construction of sewers generally. 
(a)  The city may establish and maintain separate or combined sewer systems, which systems shall be divided into district and subdistrict sewers for storm drainage or sanitary drainage or both, upon initiation by the city council. In ordering the construction of any sewers, the proceedings shall be as required under the general provisions of this chapter, but such improvements shall not be subject to remonstrance as provided for by section 15-45. 
(b)  Such sewers shall be established and constructed at such time and in such locations, of such extent, dimensions and materials, and in accordance with such full details and specifications as may be prescribed by the council. Whenever necessary, land and rights-of-way for any sewer ordered by the council may be purchased or condemned on behalf of the district, and the cost charged to such district. 
(Code 1961, § 16-20) 
Sec. 15-128. - District sewers. 
(a)  Generally. The council may order the construction of district sewers and appurtenances for sanitary drainage for districts to be known as sanitary sewer districts; the construction of district sewers and appurtenances for storm drainage for districts to be known as storm sewer districts; the construction of district sewers and appurtenances for storm and sanitary drainage for districts to be known as combined sewer districts; the construction of relief sewers or intercepting sewers, and appurtenances for storm drainage, sanitary drainage or both, for districts to be known as relief sewer districts, or intercepting sewer districts; and the construction of district sewers and appurtenances for sanitary drainage for districts to be known as special sanitary sewer districts, the construction to be approved by ordinance passed by the council. Such sewers shall be constructed so as to connect, within or without the district, with some other sufficient sewer or sewage disposal station or with some natural drainage. Such districts, except special sanitary sewer districts, may be composed of subdistricts, to be specifically named or numbered in the ordinance. District sewers, except as otherwise provided in this chapter, shall include all submains necessary to provide outlets for all subdistrict laterals within the district. Special district sewers shall include the necessary mains to provide outlets for all laterals within the special sewer district. 
(b)  Subdistrict laterals. The council may, at the time of ordering the construction of district sewers or at any time thereafter, order the construction of subdistrict laterals in any subdistrict so as to connect the subdistrict laterals with the submains or with the district main sewer, the construction to be approved by ordinance as in the case of district sewers. 
(c)  Assessment of costs. The cost of district sewers shall be assessed upon all the real estate in the district, in proportion as the area of each piece of real estate in the district is to the area of all the real estate in the district, exclusive of public highways and parks, and the cost of subdistrict laterals shall be assessed in like manner upon all the real estate in the subdistrict; provided that the construction of any submain may be omitted until such time as it may be required, in which case subdistricts so left without submains shall not be assessed for any part of the cost of submains constructed along with and as a part of the sewer district. Whenever submains so omitted are required and constructed they may be ordered as provided for other sewers, and their cost shall be assessed to the subdistricts which are supplied with submains. 
(d)  Temporary connections from property without district. Temporary connections may be made with any sewer from property lying without the district, with the consent of the council and upon such terms as it may require. 
(e)  Connections with private sewers; authority to require connections. Private sewers connected with district sewers may be constructed under such restrictions and subject to such regulations as may be prescribed by the council, but no expense shall be incurred by the city in constructing them, and the city shall have power, by ordinance, to compel the owner of any premises in any sewer district or subdistrict to connect the private sewer with the district or subdistrict sewer at his own expense. 
(f)  Connections before cost or assessment paid. No lot, premises or tract in any sewer district shall be connected with the sewer district sewer unless, before the completion, the estimated cost or, after completion, the assessment, has been paid, except that, in cases where the cost of sewers is to be assessed upon property in a district and the payment therefor had been fixed by the council to be made in installments, then connections may be made at any time when deemed advisable by the director of public works. 
(g)  Payments when assessments held illegal. If, in any sewer district, any assessment upon the lots therein for the construction of the sewer has, in any court of competent jurisdiction, been held illegal, the owner of any lot in such district shall only be permitted to connect with such sewer upon payment into the treasury for the use of the holder of warrants or bonds issued for the construction of such sewer, or, if such warrants have been taken up, then into the general fund of the city, such amount as may be fixed by ordinance. 
(h)  Provisions of chapter not applicable to certain storm sewers and drains. Nothing contained in this chapter concerning sewer districts shall be construed as applicable to storm sewers and drains acquired as a part of a street improvement program. 
(Code 1961, §§ 16-21-16-28) 
Sec. 15-129. - Sewer extensions. 
    The city may extend and maintain any existing public sewer or any district sewer main, wherever constructed, from its outlet to any point within or without the city. Such sewer extensions shall be established and constructed at such times, in locations within or without the city, of such extent, dimensions, and material, and in accordance with such full details and specifications as may be prescribed by the council. Necessary lands and rights-of-way may, upon the order of the council, be purchased or condemned on behalf of the city, and the whole cost thereof, sewer rights and rights-of-way, may be paid by the city. 
(Code 1961, § 16-29) 
Sec. 15-130. - Construction of sidewalks, curbs or curbs and gutters otherwise than in districts. 
(a)  The council may, by ordinance, order the construction or reconstruction of sidewalks, curbs or curbs and gutters otherwise than in districts whenever, in its opinion, it shall be proper, desirable, necessary or advisable, because sufficient sidewalks, curbs or curbs and gutters have been constructed in the vicinity to make it reasonable that intervening or adjoining walks, curbs or curbs and gutters should be constructed or reconstructed. In all such cases, the city manager shall notify the owner or his agent to construct or reconstruct such walks, curbs or curbs and gutters within thirty (30) days from the date of such notice. Such notice shall be in writing and served in person upon the owner or agent, if found within the city, and, if not, it may be served by registered mail addressed to his last known address or by publication for five (5) days in a newspaper published in the city. 
(b)  Whenever the owner shall fail to construct or reconstruct such walks, curbs, gutters or curbs and gutters in the time specified in the notice, the city manager may have the work done by contract or day labor by the city employees and, when completed, shall prepare a statement showing the whole cost of such improvement and apportion the same to the lots in front of which such improvements were made, according to the actual cost thereof, and certify the statement to the city council. 
(c)  The city manager shall give notice, to be served in person if the owner or agent is found within the city, or by registered mail addressed to the last known address of the owner or agent of property to be assessed for such improvement, of the cost charged against his property, and notify him that this cost will be assessed against his property by the city council at the next regular meeting held, not less than ten (10) days after the notice, at which meeting he may appear and make any objections to the assessment that he may have. 
(d)  The city council, at the proper meeting or adjournment thereof, shall, by resolution, fix and make the assessment against the property to be charged for such improvements and direct the director of finance to certify the assessment to the treasurer of the county for extension of each assessment upon his tax rolls and to collect the assessment in the same manner as other taxes are collected upon the property, unless, within thirty (30) days from the date of the fixing of the assessment by the council, the owner shall pay such assessment to the director of finance. 
(Code 1961, § 16-61) 
Sec. 15-131. - Construction of sewers otherwise than in districts. 
    Whenever the city council deems it necessary that any sewer should be constructed and which may be of such length or nature that an improvement district therefor should not be established, it may construct the sewer and assess the cost thereof against the adjacent property and property afforded a means of connection therewith. When the cost of such construction has been ascertained, the director of public works shall prepare a schedule showing the cost chargeable and shall give notice to be served in person, if the owner or agent is found within the city, or by registered mail addressed to the last known address of the owner or agent of the property to be assessed for such improvement, notifying him of the cost chargeable against his property and notifying him that this cost will be assessed against his property by the city council at the next regular meeting held not less than ten (10) days after the notice, at which meeting he may appear and make any objection to the assessment that he may have. The city council, at the proper meeting or any adjournment thereof, shall, by resolution, fix and make the assessment against the property to be charged for such improvement and direct the director of finance to certify the assessment to the treasurer of the county for extension of such assessment upon his tax rolls and to collect the assessment in the same manner as other taxes are collected upon the property, unless, within thirty (30) days from the date of the fixing of the assessment by the council, the owner shall pay such assessment to the director of finance. 
(Code 1961, § 16-62) 
Sec. 15-132. - Connection of utilities prior to paving. 
    Whenever any paving district or local improvement providing for paving is ordered under the provisions of this chapter, the city manager, if he deems it advisable, may order the owners of the abutting real estate to connect their several premises with the water and gas mains or with any other utility in the street in front of their several premises and, upon default of the owners for twenty (20) days after such order to make such connections, the city may contract for and make the connections or do the work by day labor in the manner and in accordance with the specifications prescribed for such work and the whole cost of each connection shall be assessed against the premises with which the connections are made in accordance with subsection 15-130(d). 
(Code 1961, § 16-63) 
Chapter 16 - SANITATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Penalty. 
    The penalty for a violation of this chapter shall be the same as that specifically provided in section 2-243, except that where the person charged is under the age of eighteen (18) years, there shall be no jail sentence imposed as a penalty and such other restrictions on the penalty as may be set forth in section 1-15. In the event that a violation occurs pursuant to this section and a specific penalty is not set forth in section 2-243, the penalty shall be at the court's discretion. It shall, however, still be subject to section 1-15. 
(Ord. No. 43-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 43-1995, adopted December 12, 1995, effective December 22, 1995, amended Chapter 16 by adding a new Art. III. For purposes of classification, such new provisions were included herein as § 16-1 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 16-2-16-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GARBAGE AND RUBBISH 

Sec. 16-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage and rubbish or waste means all waste and discarded materials from dwellings, flats, roominghouses, hotels, clubs, restaurants, boardinghouses, eating places, shops and places of business, including trash and debris, waste and discarded food, animal and vegetable matter, grass, weeds, wastepaper, cans, glass, ashes, offal, boxes, and cuttings from trees, lawns and gardens. Waste shall not include materials subject to manufacture into by-products or materials developed from new construction or remodeling on any premises. 
    Garbage and rubbish collection system means and includes all processing of garbage and rubbish within the city. 
    Service means the service of regular collection and hauling away of garbage and rubbish by and under the supervision of the city. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of sanitation of the city. 
    Utility charges means all garbage and rubbish collection service charges and other charges set by the city council pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1961, § 13-1; Ord. No. 16-1989, § 13-1, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 16-27. - Collection generally. 
(a)  All garbage and rubbish generated from residential property within the city shall be collected, removed and disposed of by the city. All garbage and rubbish generated from commercial and industrial use of property within the city shall be collected, removed and disposed of only by persons granted a permit by city council resolution. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, residential property shall be interpreted to include the following, as may be defined by reference to appendix A and by other chapters of this Code: 
(1)  Single-family dwellings, duplex dwellings, and mobile home dwellings (classes A, B, C, D and E); 
(2)  Home occupation uses of the dwellings listed in subsection (b)(1) of this section; 
(3)  Home-based and intermediate day care uses of the dwellings listed in subsection (b)(1) of this section; and 
(4)  Group homes. 
For purposes of this section, residential property shall exclude boardinghouses; roominghouses; hotels; motels; nursing homes; large day care use buildings; college, university and school dormitories; and trailer parks. Determination of situations not defined in this section shall be made by the public works board upon recommendation of the director of public works, subject to appeal to the city council. 
(Code 1961, § 13-3; Ord. No. 21-1989, § 13-3, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 16-28. - Collection permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to collect or haul over the city streets any trash, garbage or refuse unless such person has a permit from the city for such hauling or collection; provided that this section shall not apply to departments of the city government. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent a person from hauling or disposing of his own refuse accumulated at his residence or business in such a manner as not to endanger the public health or safety, not to create a nuisance to the inhabitants of the city, and not to litter the streets and alleys of the city. 
(Code 1961, § 13-4; Ord. No. 21-1989, § 13-4, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 16-29. - Storage for collection. 
    Garbage and rubbish shall only be kept for collection upon the property which generated it. It shall be unlawful for any person, by agreement or otherwise, to collect the garbage or rubbish generated upon one (1) property and deposit it on any other property within the city, except in city-owned: 
(1)  Rollout receptacles; or 
(2)  Superintendent-designated shared non- 
wheeled receptacles or those receptacles provided by city-permitted trash and garbage collectors. Evidence, such as envelopes, boxes, cartons, bills, checks or any other documents with a person's name found thereon, shall be prima facie evidence that person deposited such items on other property within the city. 
(Code 1961, § 13-5; Ord. No. 16-1989, § 13-5, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89; Ord. No. 9-1990, 8-28-90, eff. 8-31-90) 
Sec. 16-30. - Establishment of service charges; charge for vacant residence. 
(a)  Fees for garbage and rubbish service shall be considered utility charges. Fees shall be recommended by the director of public works to the city council for review and set by city council resolution and reviewed annually. 
(b)  All residences within the city for which garbage and rubbish service is being charged by the city, upon becoming vacant, shall continue to be charged for garbage and rubbish service as long as water service is being provided to such residences. 
(Code 1961, § 13-5.1; Ord. No. 16-1989, § 13-5.1, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89; Ord. No. 21-1989, § 13-5.1, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 16-31. - Billing of service charges. 
    All utility charges established pursuant to this article shall be billed pursuant to the procedure in section 21-26 et seq. 
(Code 1961, § 13-6; Ord. No. 21-1989, § 13-6, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 16-32. - Sanitation enterprise fund.
