    All funds collected by the city for utility charges provided in this article shall be credited to the sanitation enterprise fund created by Ordinance No. 19, series of 1988, and all expenditures from this fund shall be appropriated by the city council. 
(Code 1961, § 13-7; Ord. No. 16-1989, § 13-7, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89) 
Sec. 16-33. - Unlawful deposits and accumulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or place any garbage or rubbish in such a manner that the garbage or rubbish is or tends to become a nuisance, or in such a manner as endangers or tends to endanger the public health. It shall be unlawful for any person having the occupancy, control or management of any premises to cause or permit any garbage or rubbish to be accumulated thereon in such a manner that the garbage or rubbish is or tends to become a nuisance or in such a manner as endangers or tends to endanger the public health. It shall be unlawful for any person to, in any manner, throw, place, scatter, deposit or bury any garbage or rubbish in or upon any public street, alley or other public place or upon the premises of another, except in city-owned: 
(1)  Rollout receptacles; or 
(2)  Superintendent-designated shared non- wheeled receptacles or those receptacles provided by city-permitted trash and garbage collectors. Evidence, such as envelopes, boxes, cartons, bills, checks or any other documents with a person's name found thereon in any public street, alley or other public place or upon the premises of another, shall be prima facie evidence that person threw, placed, scattered, deposited or buried such items. 
(Code 1961, § 13-8; Ord. No. 21-1989, § 13-8, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 9-1990, 8-28-90, eff. 8-31-90) 
Sec. 16-34. - Prohibited and unlawful activities. 
(a)  It shall be prohibited and unlawful for any person to deposit any uncontained waste, discarded food, animal and vegetable matter (except grass clippings, leaves, and tree limbs) or offal in any city-owned garbage or rubbish container. 
(b)  It shall be prohibited and unlawful to deposit any tree limbs or trimmings more than four (4) inches in diameter and three (3) feet in length; construction, demolition or remodeling debris; concrete, dirt, sod, plaster or heavy materials; hot ashes or hot coals; flammable liquids, such as, but not limited to, cleaning fluid, waste oils, gasoline; small appliances and small furniture items which will not allow lids to close on the containers; tires; herbicides, pesticides, used batteries, acids or solid iron in any city-owned garbage or rubbish container. 
(c)  Any and all such prohibited and unlawful items stated in this section and found by any city official in a city-owned garbage or rubbish container shall be prima facie evidence that the person who is permitted to use such city-owned garbage or rubbish container deposited the same therein. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a parent of a child under eighteen (18) years of age or for any person in loco parentis with a child under eighteen (18) years of age to permit such child to play in, on or around any city-owned garbage or rubbish container. 
(Ord. No. 9-1990, 8-28-90, eff. 8-31-90) 
Sec. 16-35. - Vehicles used for collection and disposal. 
(a)  All wagons, trucks, cars or vehicles used for the collection and removal of garbage within the city shall at all times be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall have tight beds or containers from which no garbage, litter or liquid may escape. 
(b)  All public or private vehicles used for the collection, disposal or transportation of trash shall have enclosed bodies or suitable provision for covering the body. Provision and use of a tarpaulin or canvas cover to enclose open bodies of collection vehicles may be permitted when specifically approved by the superintendent of sanitation. 
(c)  Vehicles used for the collection, disposal or transportation of trash shall have watertight metal bodies or containers of easily cleanable construction, shall be cleaned at sufficient frequency to prevent nuisance or insect breeding, and shall be maintained in good repair. 
(Code 1961, § 13-9; Ord. No. 21-1989, § 13-9, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 16-36. - Disposal sites. 
    All garbage and rubbish disposal sites owned or under the control of the city, together with all matter whatsoever deposited or existing thereon, shall be the property of the city, and no person shall enter upon such sites or carry off, dispose of or in any manner disturb or molest any matter or thing deposited or existing upon such sites, except under the direction or authority of the superintendent. 
(Code 1961, § 13-10; Ord. No. 16-1989, § 13-10, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89) 
Sec. 16-37. - Burning. 
(a)  Except as provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to set on fire or burn any solid waste, garbage and rubbish, or any hay, grass, leaves, weeds, wood or other combustible or flammable materials, including wastepaper, or anything whatsoever, in any ash pit or other receptacle or upon the ground, except in an approved incinerator meeting the minimum standards as set forth in the Air Pollution Control Act of 1970, a law of the state, provided that a permit therefor shall first have been obtained from the appropriate air pollution control authority. Any such act is hereby declared a nuisance because of smoke or odor, and also because of state law, rules and regulations. 
(b)  A person wishing to burn weeds, grass and other vegetation may obtain a permit to do so from the fire chief, or his designated representative. The permit shall limit the date, time and manner of burning; the material to be burned; the procedure or equipment which shall be allowed for burning; and any additional conditions or circumstances which may be required by the fire chief to provide for safety. All such permits shall be revocable by the fire chief or his designated representative at any time. 
(Code 1961, § 13-11; Ord. No. 16-1987, § 13-11, 9-8-87, eff. 9-29-89) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7. 
Chapter 17 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Parks, library and recreation department, § 2-166; comprehensive planning, § 2-296 et seq.; open containers of alcoholic beverages prohibited on streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public ways or public places and in any vehicle, § 3-12; animal shelter established, § 4-4; parking restrictions, § 10-46 et seq.; parks and recreation areas, Ch. 13; public improvements, planning, construction, assessments and collection procedures, Ch. 15; specifications and requirements for improvements in subdivisions, § 18-76 et seq.; drainage and storm sewer specification and design requirements in subdivisions, § 18-103; trailer park regulations, § 20-26 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Installation of cable television facilities in streets, proposed streets and other public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install or maintain, within any public street in the city or within any other public property of the city or within any privately owned area within the city which has not yet become a public street but is designated or delineated as a proposed public street on any tentative subdivision map approved by the city, any equipment or facilities for distributing any television signals or radio signals through a CATV system, unless a permit authorizing such use of such street or property or area has first been obtained and unless such permit is in full force and effect. 
(Code 1961, § 19-6.1) 
Cross reference- Cable communication systems, Ch. 5.5; licenses, permits and business regulations, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 17-2. - Obstructions generally. 
    No person shall encumber or obstruct any street, alley, curb, storm sewer, drainageway, or sidewalk with building materials or any article or thing, whether with merchandise, or otherwise, without having first obtained the permission of the director of public works. 
(Code 1961, § 24-7) 
Sec. 17-3. - Obstruction of streets by trains. 
    No railroad company shall obstruct any street within the city by stopping any train upon or by leaving any car or locomotive engine standing on its track where the track intersects or crosses any street, except for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers or to receive necessary fuel and water. In no case shall such obstruction exceed five (5) minutes for each train, car or locomotive engine. 
(Code 1961, § 19-27) 
Sec. 17-4. - Cellar or vault openings on streets and sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have or keep open any cellar door, pit or vault or other subterraneous opening on any street or sidewalk or to suffer the opening to be left open or to be kept in an insecure condition so that passersby will be in danger of falling into such cellar, pit, vault or other opening. 
(Code 1961, § 24-8) 
Sec. 17-5. - Construction and repair of curbs. 
(a)  Notice. When the director of public works determines the necessity of constructing, reconstructing or repairing a curb, it shall, through the director of public works, notify the owner, agent or person having charge of the property adjoining the street where the curb is to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired. Such notice shall be in writing and shall specify the particular work to be done. 
(b)  Failure to comply with order; assessment. Whenever the director of public works decides that any curbing shall be constructed or repaired, he may order the curbing constructed or repaired by the owner of the property fronting on the street where the curbing is to be constructed or repaired. If such owner does not construct the curbing or repair the curbing as directed by the director of public works within thirty (30) days after service of the notice, the city may construct or repair the curbing and assess the cost thereof to the lots fronting upon the curb so constructed or repaired pro rata to each lot for its proportionate share of the cost of such construction. The amount shall be assessed and shall be a lien upon the property pursuant to the procedure in section 21-26 et seq. 
(Code 1961, §§ 24-5, 24-6) 
Secs. 17-6-17-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Sidewalk requirements in subdivisions, § 18-106. 

Sec. 17-21. - Obstruction. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any sidewalk within the limits of the city by throwing debris thereon or allowing weeds to grow thereon in front of the property belonging to such person. The deliberate placing of a hose and sprinkler so that water therefrom will obstruct the walk shall be deemed an obstruction within the meaning of this section. 
(Code 1961, § 24-7) 
Sec. 17-22. - Removal of snow, ice, rubbish, etc. 
(a)  The owner, occupant or agent of any property adjacent to a public sidewalk shall use diligence to keep such walk safe for pedestrians. It shall be unlawful for such owner, occupant or agent to permit snow, ice, dirt, mud, rubbish or filth to remain on the sidewalk longer than twenty-four (24) hours after the termination of the falling of such snow or the accumulation of such ice, dirt, mud, rubbish or filth. If the sidewalk is not paved or flagged, it shall be necessary to remove such snow, ice, dirt, mud, rubbish or filth from a space four (4) feet in width to allow for safe pedestrian passage. 
(b)  If the snow, ice, mud, dirt, rubbish or filth is not removed from any sidewalk as required by subsection (a) of this section, the superintendent of streets may cause such material to be removed and shall certify the entire cost thereof, including the cost of inspection and other incidental costs in connection therewith, to the director of finance, to be considered as utility charges, pursuant to the procedure in section 21-26 et seq. 
(Code 1961, §§ 24-2, 24-3) 
State Law reference- Authority of the city to require the owners and occupants of abutting property to keep sidewalks clean and free of snow, C.R.S. 31-12-101. 
Sec. 17-23. - Repair. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of premises abutting on any sidewalk in the city to maintain the sidewalk in good repair. It shall be unlawful for any such person to allow such sidewalk to become or to continue so out of repair as to endanger persons lawfully using such sidewalk. 
(Code 1961, § 24-1) 
Sec. 17-24. - Structures on public rights-of-way. 
(a)  The city manager, or designee, is hereby authorized to issue permits for the purpose of erecting, placing, or causing to be placed fences, retaining walls, planters, benches, and other seating, or like structures, primarily to promote short term outdoor sales, on public rights-of-way. 
(b)  Said permits may be issued only to owners of property or the lessee of real property operating in accordance with the provisions of his or her lease and with the consent of the lessor which abut public rights-of-way, and shall be limited to that portion of a right-of-way defined by the projected lot lines of the property owner or lessee applying for said permit. 
(c)  Application for a permit shall be filed with the city manager, or designee, and shall include the following: 
(1)  The applicant's name, address and phone number. 
(2)  The legal description and common address of the private property and adjacent sidewalk or other public right-of-way. 
(3)  A complete description of the proposed use, including a statement of the sizes and quantity of tables, chairs, and service equipment proposed to be placed upon the sidewalk or other public right-of-way if the use is intended for a sidewalk café. 
(4)  Site plan: A plan of the portion of public right-of-way proposed for use by the abutting property owner or lessee. Said plan shall be drawn to scale and shall include dimensions; location of the proposed use; description of the proposed use, including height, types of material, and general character; and a legal description of the area proposed for use. The city manager, or designee, may require further information as necessary to adequately determine the safety of the proposed use. 
(5)  Hold harmless: The owner/applicant shall hold the city harmless against any claims, liabilities, damages, or lawsuits (including the city's attorneys' fees) arising from the location of said use on the public right-of-way. 
(d)  All items permitted under this section shall not be placed within two (2) feet from the curb. A minimum four-foot sidewalk aisle shall be maintained for pedestrian travel at all times. 
(e)  The city manager, or designee, shall timely review all applications and may approve the application, deny the application for cause, or refer the application to the applicant for further information. 
(f)  Approved applications shall be forwarded by the city manager, or designee, to the public works director for the issuance of a building permit, if required. 
(g)  Decorative type landscaping may be installed on any public right-of-way without approval of the city manager, or designee, provided said landscaping does not encroach upon the four-foot sidewalk aisle. 
(h)  Any permit issued for a permitted use on public right-of-way shall continue at the sole discretion of the city. 
(i)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, the city may remove or cause to be removed, with reasonable prior notice, any use of public right-of-way permitted under the provisions of these regulations, for the purpose of widening, constructing, or otherwise improving any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way or use, without compensation to the owner of said permitted use. 
(Ord. No. 6-2016, 6-14-16, eff. 6-24-16) 
Secs. 17-25-17-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 21. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency means any unforeseeable situation requiring excavation of a street or sidewalk to prevent imminent danger to the health or safety of natural persons, major property damage or loss, or loss of necessary services to a substantial number of natural persons. 
    Excavate means to cut, open, dig up, disturb, deface, construct, repair, maintain, replace, install, reinstall, bore, jack, tunnel, or cause such work to be done. 
    Permit means an excavation permit issued pursuant to division 2 of this article. 
    Street means any public street, alley, sidewalk, curb, gutter, public right-of-way, thoroughfare, and public property within the city. 
(Code 1961, § 24-19) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-42. - Applicability of article. 
    This article shall apply to any person who for any reason excavates in any street or sidewalk in the city for the purpose of installing, maintaining or repairing any underground or surface utility or structure or for any other purpose whatsoever, or who causes such work to be done. 
(Code 1961, § 24-20) 
Sec. 17-43. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any violation of this article shall be punishable under section 1-15 in addition to any increase of fees which may be provided for in this article. In addition, any violation of this article shall be grounds for the suspension of the permit and stoppage of any excavation or other work by the director of public works until the violation is corrected. 
(Code 1961, § 24-46) 
Sec. 17-44. - Administration of article; authority of director of public works. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the director of public works to administer this article. The director of public works is specifically empowered by this article to promulgate rules and regulations having to do with the form of permit, the required quality of work and the standards and specifications therefor, the procedures for inspection, and the information to be required before a permit will be issued pursuant to the requirements of this article. All requirements of the director of public works with regard to backfill material, procedures and soil compaction shall be adhered to. The director of public works shall have the authority to stop any excavation within the city until the provisions of this article are complied with. 
(Code 1961, § 24-28) 
Sec. 17-45. - Liability of permittee. 
    Any person who excavates in any street in the city shall be answerable for any damage occasioned to persons, animals or property by the reason of carelessness or negligence or by any intentional act connected with such work, and by obtaining a permit for such work shall thereby be deemed to consent and agree to hold the city harmless from any such damage or injury. The acceptance of a permit under this article shall be deemed to be the permittee's acceptance of the duty to repair any and all damage to city pipes, cables, lines, utilities or structures which may occur due to the permittee's excavation. The director of public works shall stop any work being done by the permittee within the city and shall not issue any new permits until such damage is paid for in full. 
(Code 1961, § 24-44) 
Sec. 17-46. - Obstruction of street; placing materials in sidewalk or gutter. 
    No person shall stop or obstruct more than the space of one (1) block and one (1) intersection at any one (1) time in any one (1) street or keep the street blocked up for more than one (1) day after the excavation is completed, unless written permission is first obtained from the director of public works. No person performing any excavation work may place any dirt or other materials on any sidewalk or in any gutter and all excavation work shall be performed so as to permit the free passage of water along the gutter. 
(Code 1961, § 24-35) 
Sec. 17-47. - Placement of lights and barricades. 
    No person shall excavate in any street or sidewalk in the city without providing, during the nighttime, sufficient warning lights, to be placed with a suitable barricade or temporary fence as provided in section 17-48 around such excavation. During the daytime, the barricade or temporary fence shall be maintained and be kept in place, but warning lights shall not be required. The suitability and sufficiency of the barricades and lights required in this section shall be determined by the director of public works. No excavation shall be left open overnight except by written permission of the director of public works. 
(Code 1961, § 24-36) 
Sec. 17-48. - Barriers for excavations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, including contractors and city officers and employees, to make any excavation or dig any hole, drain or ditch in any street or sidewalk without providing, during the night, a temporary fence or suitable barrier around or in front of such excavation in order to prevent persons, animals or vehicles from falling into it pursuant to requirements on file in the office of the public works department and approved by the director of public works. 
(Code 1961, § 24-9) 
Sec. 17-49. - Traffic safety devices required. 
    Every excavation in any street in the city shall be protected at all times by traffic safety devices approved by the director of public works, in order to minimize the disruption of the flow of traffic in the vicinity of the work. 
(Code 1961, § 24-3) 
Sec. 17-50. - Damaging or removing safety devices. 
    No person shall damage, displace, remove or interfere with any barricade or temporary fence, warning light or other safety device which is placed around or about any excavation or construction work in any street in the city pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1961, § 24-38) 
Sec. 17-51. - Protection of utilities and structures. 
    Any person who is subject to this article when undertaking a project of excavation shall cooperate with the city and other utilities having facilities in the same area by inquiring as to the location of all utilities and structures located aboveground and underground which might be affected by the proposed excavation. At all times, the installations, utilities and structures of the city upon or below ground shall have priority in the public streets. 
(Code 1961, § 24-39) 
Sec. 17-52. - Boring or tunneling. 
    If the director of public works determines it to be in the best interest of the city to require the applicant for a permit to bore, jack or tunnel a utility line or other line or pipe that is to be placed in a public street instead of making a cut in the street therefor, he shall have the authority to impose such requirement and issue a permit for such boring, jacking or tunneling. 
(Code 1961, § 24-34) 
Sec. 17-53. - Time for completion of work. 
    All work authorized by a permit shall be commenced within a reasonable time after the issuance of the permit and shall be diligently and continuously performed until completion. If weather, process of law or any other unexpected obstacle causes work to be stopped for so long a time that public travel will be unreasonably obstructed, the director of public works may order the excavation refilled and repaved as if the work contemplated in the permit were actually completed. 
(Code 1961, § 24-33) 
Sec. 17-54. - Completion of work by city. 
    In conformity with section 17-53, if, after notice by the director of public works, the permittee fails to complete his work within forty-eight (48) hours subsequent to such notice, the city may complete the work created by any excavation. The costs of such completion, plus fifteen (15) percent, shall be charged by the city to the permittee. 
(Code 1961, § 24-43) 
Sec. 17-55. - Duty to repair damages. 
    Any person who excavates in any street or sidewalk in the city shall replace, repair or reinstall any damage and disruption whatsoever to the streets or sidewalks of the city, including paving and surfacing, caused by construction, excavation, maintenance and repair of any utility or structure, according to the specifications of the director of public works. The city may make the repairs, replacement and reinstallation at the option of the director of public works and bill the person therefor to ensure the quality of the work and to preserve the character of the streets and sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1961, § 24-41) 
Sec. 17-56. - Duty to make corrections. 
    In the event of settlement, subsidence or failure of a repair made by the permittee of a particular excavation or part thereof within a period of three (3) years after the street or sidewalk repair is completed, the permittee who had performed the excavation work shall be notified by the director of public works and be given reasonable opportunity to correct the condition to the satisfaction of the director of public works. If the permittee fails to correct the condition to the satisfaction of the director of public works and the city is required to correct the condition, the permittee shall be responsible for repaving and repair costs occasioned thereby plus fifteen (15) percent. The permittee shall discontinue any and all other work in the streets within the city and shall be issued no additional excavation permits until such time as the required repair has been completed and paid for. 
(Code 1961, § 24-40) 
Sec. 17-57. - Extension of period of repair. 
    A failure to have a final inspection performed by the director of public works or his designee under the rules and regulations promulgated by the director of public works shall extend the commencement of the three-year period of repair under section 17-56 until such time as a final inspection and final signature is attached to the permit. 
(Code 1961, § 24-46) 
Sec. 17-58. - Installation of utilities in new developments. 
    In any area of new development, it shall be the duty of every person to install all mains, conduits, cables, poles and the like which may be deemed necessary for water, gas, sewer, storm drainage, telephone and electricity facilities or any other utilities, prior to the installation, construction or paving of any street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1961, § 24-42) 
Sec. 17-59. - Hindering or obstructing work prohibited. 
    It is a violation of this article to hinder or obstruct any excavation or resurfacing operation or other work done in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1961, § 24-45) 
Secs. 17-60-17-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 17-76. - Required; application. 
(a)  No person shall excavate in any street or sidewalk in the city without having first secured a permit therefor from the director of public works. An application for the permit shall be made at least seven (7) days prior to the planned excavation. 
(b)  Every person desiring to do any excavation work shall apply to the director of public works for a permit therefor, on a form provided by the director of public works, stating the applicant's name; the location, length, width and purpose of the proposed excavation; the proposed dates of commencement and completion of the work; plans and specifications for the work; a statement that the work will be performed in strict compliance with the plans, specifications, procedures, rules and regulations approved by the director of public works; and any other information which may be required under the rules and regulations by the director of public works. The application shall be accompanied by a site plan giving the exact location of the proposed excavation and utility or structure to be installed, repaired, maintained or replaced. The site plan shall include the location of all the existing utilities and structures in the vicinity of the proposed excavation and shall be provided to the director of public works in duplicate. 
(Code 1961, §§ 24-21, 24-26) 
Sec. 17-77. - Persons to whom permits may be issued. 
    Permits shall be issued only to those persons who are currently licensed as building contractors under chapter 9, article II, to public and private utility company employees, and to natural persons determined by the director of public works to be performing work on a sidewalk, driveway, curb, gutter or curb cut for the benefit of the person's primary private residence. 
(Code 1961, § 24-31) 
Sec. 17-78. - Fee. 
    Applicants for a permit shall pay a fee in an amount as set by resolution of the city council and kept on file in the office of the city clerk, to the director of public works. The fee shall accompany all applications for permits, for issuance of the permit and inspection of the completed work. No permit shall be for more than one (1) excavation project. 
(Code 1961, § 24-23) 
Sec. 17-79. - Penalty for commencing work without obtaining permit. 
    The director of public works shall suspend all operations of any person who makes any excavation in any street in the city without first having obtained a permit as provided in this division. Such person shall obtain a permit applicable to that particular excavation and shall pay twice the usual fee that would have been charged if a permit had properly been obtained prior to making the excavation. Such penalty fees shall be in addition to any penalties that may be imposed by any court for violation of this article. 
(Code 1961, § 24-24) 
Sec. 17-80. - Proof of insurance required prior to issuance. 
(a)  Every applicant, before being granted a permit, shall furnish the city with proof of insurance, in such form as is approved by the director of public works, with an insurance company licensed to do business in the state, with the following provisions for coverage, including, but not limited to, liability coverage, including motor vehicle, bodily injury and property damage, in the amount of four hundred thousand dollars ($400,000.00) per occurrence with an annual aggregate coverage of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). Such insurance shall cover all operations of the permittee and all of his vehicles to be used in the course of his operations in the city. 
(b)  Any other provisions of this article or this Code notwithstanding, the amount of insurance shall at no time be less than that required under the statutes of the state under those sections dealing with governmental immunity. A waiver of this requirement may be made by the director of public works for a natural person determined by the director of public works to be performing work on a sidewalk, driveway, curb, gutter or curb cut for the benefit of his primary residence. 
(Code 1961, § 24-27) 
Sec. 17-81. - Conditions on issuance. 
    Permits shall be issued on the condition that all work performed shall be in accordance with this article and the rules, regulations and specifications promulgated by the director of public works, all of which are intended to provide for the proper care and maintenance of the streets in the city and the safety and protection of the persons and property of the general public. 
(Code 1961, § 24-29) 
Sec. 17-82. - Permit to be kept on site. 
    The permit shall be kept at the site of the excavation while the work is in progress and shall be exhibited upon request to any police officer, the director of public works, or any other authorized representative of the city. 
(Code 1961, § 24-22) 
Sec. 17-83. - Emergency work. 
    Any person may make an excavation in any street or sidewalk in response to an emergency. However, such person must immediately notify the director of public works or, if the emergency situation is discovered after regular business hours, the police department, of such excavation, and must obtain a permit and pay the required fees on the first working day after making such excavation. Should such person fail to make this notification and obtain the required permit, the matter will be dealt with as provided in section 17-79. 
(Code 1961, § 24-25) 
Sec. 17-84. - Waiver. 
    The director of public works shall waive the permit requirements of this article for any excavation done by any city crew or employee who is working under the supervision of the director of public works. 
(Code 1961, § 24-30) 
Sec. 17-85. - Record of permits. 
    The director of public works shall prepare and keep a record of permits, numbered in the order in which they were issued. The records shall show the name and address of the permittee; the location, nature, purpose and extent of the excavation or opening; the time in which the street is to be restored; the permit fee; and such other and further items that will enable anyone to obtain a complete history of each permit from its issuance to its termination. The copies of the permits kept by the director of public works, properly bound, may be used as a basis for such record. 
(Code 1961, § 24-32) 
Secs. 17-86-17-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CEMETERY 

Sec. 17-101. - Plat; official title; description. 
    The plat of the cemetery recorded on March 10, 1970, in the office of the county clerk at book 4, page 38, record no. 485-490, showing all boundaries, sections, lots, divisions, roads, drives and paths, is hereby adopted as the official plat of the cemetery which shall be known as Riverside Cemetery. The Riverside Cemetery is established upon property owned by the city located and described in deed no. 37240 recorded in the office of the county clerk in book 81, page 437; in deed no. 303206 recorded in book 333, page 514; in deed no. 403644 recorded in book 500, page 57; and in deed no. 404726 recorded in book 501, page 433; and other land acquired or to be acquired by the city for cemetery purposes. 
(Code 1961, §§ 22-1, 22-2) 
Sec. 17-102. - Authority of department of parks, library and recreation. 
    The department of parks, library and recreation shall have the entire supervision and control of the cemetery and is hereby authorized to make all necessary rules and regulations governing future additions, maintenance, care and control of the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-3) 
Sec. 17-103. - Superintendent. 
(a)  The department of parks, library and recreation with the approval of the city manager, shall appoint a superintendent of the cemetery, whose duty it shall be to have charge of the cemetery and of the maintenance and improvement of the grounds. He shall have charge of all interments in the cemetery and keep a record of the interments, showing the exact location in the cemetery of the lot in which the remains of any deceased person have been deposited. 
(b)  The superintendent shall require the exhibition to him of a properly executed burial permit, as required by the state, before allowing any interment to take place in the cemetery. 
(c)  The superintendent shall enforce the provisions of this Code, including this chapter, and all rules and regulations adopted by the department of parks, library and recreation for the government of the cemetery. 
(d)  The superintendent shall have charge of the digging of all graves in the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-4) 
Sec. 17-104. - Fees. 
    All prices for sale of cemetery spaces and all fees for openings, closings, disinterments, transfers of ownership of spaces and all other prices, fees and charges shall be set by city council resolution and reviewed annually. Adjustments may be made in such prices, fees and charges, following review, by city council resolution. 
(Ord. No. 17-1989, § 22-26, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89) 
Sec. 17-105. - Payment and deposit of funds; perpetual care fund. 
    All money received for the sale of lots, digging of graves and other services about the cemetery shall be paid directly to the director of finance, who shall give proper receipts therefor. All money so received shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. All money received for perpetual care shall be placed in a separate fund by the director of finance and invested as provided by law. Perpetual care of lots and graves shall be limited to the income or earnings of the perpetual care fund, and no part of the principal shall be expended for such care. 
(Code 1961, § 22-6) 
Sec. 17-106. - Sale of lots. 
(a)  The prices of such lots, including those with the furnishing of perpetual care, in the cemetery, as the city council shall deem advisable to offer for sale, shall be filed with the director of finance, who shall keep an accurate record of all sales of lots in the cemetery, showing the name of the purchaser with the description of the lot purchased in a book provided by the city for that purpose. 
(b)  When any person selects a lot, the cemetery superintendent shall give such person a memorandum showing the legal description of the lot. Upon presentation to the director of finance and payment of the purchase price of the lot, the director of finance shall cause a proper deed of conveyance giving a right to burial only to be executed to the purchaser, signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk and duly authenticated under the seal of the city. Such deed shall forbid the use of the lot for any purpose other than the burial of human bodies and the purchaser shall expressly agree in the deed to observe such restriction, and shall agree also that the planting and decorating of the lot and of the whole cemetery and the placing of monuments, markers, vaults and any structure or object above the surface of the ground shall be subject to the general supervision and approval of the city council and its officers and employees appointed for that purpose, particularly the superintendent, and that the purchaser's rights shall be subject to such reasonable rules and regulations as shall be adopted from time to time relative to the use of the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-5) 
Sec. 17-107. - Burials and disinterments. 
    No interment shall be made in the cemetery and no body shall be removed therefrom until the proper death certificate and all permits required by law and all the information necessary to complete the records of the cemetery have been furnished the director of finance or the superintendent of the cemetery. No interment shall be made within the cemetery without a permit from the director of finance. The permit shall be presented to the superintendent of the cemetery and returned by him to the office of the director of finance after interment. 
(Code 1961, § 22-7) 
Sec. 17-108. - City not to be liable for property loss or damage. 
    The city shall take reasonable precautions to protect lot owners and the property rights of owners within the cemetery from loss or damage, but it expressly shall not be liable for loss or damage beyond its control, and particularly from damage caused by the elements, an act of God, common enemy, thieves, vandals and the like, whether the damage be direct or consequential. 
Sec. 17-109. - Foundations of monuments and other structures. 
    All foundations for monuments and other structures in the cemetery must be of sufficient depth and stability to support the proposed structure and, to this end, no structure may be erected until the foundation therefor has been approved by the superintendent of the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-8) 
Sec. 17-110. - Rights of superintendent regarding maintenance and improvements on lots. 
(a)  The superintendent of the cemetery shall have the right to enter upon any lot and cut down or remove any tree or shrub or any part thereof which is deemed detrimental to the cemetery or unsightly or inconvenient to the public or to adjoining lots. He shall also be authorized to enter upon any lot to make any improvement deemed for the advantage of the grounds. 
(b)  If any vegetation, object or structure or any part of any vegetation, object or structure within the cemetery is deemed to be objectionable or unsightly by the superintendent, he shall have the right to remove the vegetation, object or structure. 
(Code 1961, §§ 22-9, 22-11) 
Sec. 17-111. - Lot owners not to interfere with lot grade or cemetery plan. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any lot in the cemetery to change the grade of such lot or interfere in any way with the general plan for the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-12) 
Sec. 17-112. - Cleanup of rubbish, tools, etc. 
    All rubbish, unsightly material or debris accumulating in the cemetery from any work or any cause must be removed at once by the person causing its accumulation. All derricks, tools and the like must also be removed immediately upon completion of work and the grounds left in as good a condition as found. 
(Code 1961, § 22-10) 
Sec. 17-113. - Excavations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation in the cemetery without the written consent of the superintendent of the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-15) 
Sec. 17-114. - Possession and discharge of firearms. 
    Section 12-8 regarding firearms, applies to the cemetery. It shall be unlawful to possess any such weapons in the cemetery, except to the extent permitted by the cemetery superintendent for military funerals and related Memorial Day services. Permitted use shall not include the discharge of any live ammunition or projectile. 
(Code 1961, § 22-13) 
Sec. 17-115. - Removal of property. 
    It shall be unlawful to remove any object from any place in the cemetery without the consent of the superintendent. 
(Code 1961, § 22-14) 
Sec. 17-116. - Obstruction of drives and paths. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any drive or path in the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-16) 
Sec. 17-117. - Injuring stones, graves, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful to in any way injure, deface or destroy any stone, structure, grave, flower, tree, shrub, vine or any other thing in the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-17) 
Sec. 17-118. - Driving over closed paths or roadways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle over any path or roadway in the cemetery which has been closed to vehicular traffic by the superintendent of the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-8) 
Sec. 17-119. - Pets and animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit a pet or any animal owned by him, or a pet or any animal in his custody or control, to run at large within the cemetery. Persons having pets or animals shall promptly remove any excrement caused by the pet or animal. 
(Code 1961, § 22-19) 
Sec. 17-120. - Use of gates. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the cemetery except through the cemetery gates. 
(Code 1961, § 22-20) 
Sec. 17-121. - Disturbances. 
    Except as provided in this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to disturb the quiet of the cemetery by any noise of any kind, or to disturb the decorum of the cemetery by offensive conduct. 
(Code 1961, § 22-21) 
Sec. 17-122. - Trespassing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or remain within the cemetery after the gates are closed or after having been asked by the superintendent to leave. 
(Code 1961, § 22-22) 
Sec. 17-123. - Commercial activity. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, solicit, sell or peddle flowers, plants, monuments or any commodity or service within the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-23) 
Sec. 17-124. - Speed limit. 
    It shall be unlawful to drive any vehicle at a speed greater than posted within the cemetery. 
(Code 1961, § 22-24) 
Chapter 18 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Community development department, § 2-151 et seq.; the community development department shall be responsible for advising the city council, planning commission, etc., regarding all matters relating to planning and zoning, § 2-153; comprehensive planning, § 2-296 et seq.; standards in areas of special flood hazards for subdivision proposals, § 8-66(4); specific standards in all areas of special flood hazards where base flood elevation data has been provided, § 8-67; trailer park regulations, § 20-26 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
(a)  The following rules shall apply in interpreting this chapter unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
(1)  Words used in the singular shall include the plural and words used in the plural shall include the singular, and words in the present tense shall include the future. 
(2)  The word, "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary. 
(3)  The word "may" is discretionary and not mandatory. 
(4)  The word "lot" shall include the words "piece" and "parcel." 
(5)  The word "building" shall include all structures of every kind. 
(6)  The phrase "used for" shall include the phrases "arranged for," "intended for," "maintained for," and "occupied for." 
(7)  The word "council" means the mayor and the council. 
(8)  The word "commission" means the planning commission. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a minor public way which is used primarily for secondary vehicular service access to the rear or side of properties otherwise abutting a street. 
    Applicant means the owner, or representative of the owner, of land proposed to be subdivided. Consent shall be required from the legal owner of the premises. 
    Block means a piece of land usually bounded on all sides by streets or other transportation routes such as railroad lines, or by physical barriers such as water bodies or public open space, and not traversed by a through street. 
    Building means any structure used or intended for supporting or sheltering any use or occupancy. 
    Building line means a line extending across the full width of a lot parallel to the street right-of-way and in front of which no building may be constructed. 
    Cul-de-sac means a dead-end street terminating in a vehicular turnaround area. 
    Dedication means the transfer of property from private ownership to the public. 
    Developer: See Applicant. 
    Easement means a right given by the owner of land to another party for specific limited use of that land. 
    Final subdivision plat means the final map or drawing, described in this chapter, on which the subdivider's plan of subdivision is presented to the planning commission for approval and which, if approved, may be submitted to the city council for final approval and subsequent recording. 
    Flood or flooding means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland or tidal waves or the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Frontage means the side of a lot abutting on a street and ordinarily regarded as the front of the lot. 
    Grade means the lowest point of elevation of the finished surface of the ground, paving or sidewalk within the area between the building and the property line or, when the property line is more than five (5) feet from the building, between the building and a line five (5) feet from the building. 
    Improvements: See Lot improvements or Public improvements. 
    Lot means any continuous parcel of land legally defined by survey abutting a dedicated public way, except that a lot in a residential district need not abut a dedicated public way where access is provided by recorded plat, reservation, deed, covenant or contract. 
    Lot area means the horizontal area of the lot exclusive of any area in a street or recorded way open to public use. The lot area required for zoning compliance shall be land other than that under any water body or wetland. Lot area shall be calculated on a square footage basis with an acre equaling forty-three thousand five hundred sixty (43,560) square feet. 
    Lot frontage means that portion of a lot fronting upon and providing rights of access to a dedicated street. Lot frontage shall be measured continuously along only one (1) street. 
    Lot improvement means a physical betterment of real property, which includes rough and final grading and such other improvement as shall be specifically required by the planning commission due to reasons of topography or other conditions and as shall be deemed necessary by the planning commission for the general health, safety and welfare of the citizens. 
    Lot line means the lines bounding a lot defined as follows: 
(1)  Front lot line means the line separating the lot from the street on the narrow side. 
(2)  Rear lot line means the line opposite the front lot line. 
(3)  Side lot line means any lot line other than front lot line or rear lot line. 
    Lot of record means a lot for which a recorded plat or deed shows that it was owned separately and individually from adjoining tracts of land at a time when the recording of a lot of such area, depth and width in the same location would not have been prohibited by applicable ordinance or any amendment thereto. 
    Lots, types of: 
(1)  Corner lot means a lot abutting two (2) or more streets at their intersection or upon two (2) parts of the same street and where, in either case, the interior angle formed by the intersection of street lines does not exceed one hundred thirty-five (135) degrees. 
(2)  Interior means a lot other than a corner lot with one (1) frontage on a street other than the alley. 
(3)  Reversed corner lot means a corner lot having its side street line substantially a continuation of the front lot line of the first lot to its rear. 
(4)  Through lot means a lot which has public streets adjoining both front and back lot lines. 
    Lot width means the distance parallel to the front lot line measured between side lot lines through that part of the building or structure where the lot is narrowest. 
    Major subdivision means all subdivisions not classified as minor subdivisions, including but not limited to subdivisions of four (4) or more lots, or any size subdivision requiring any new street or extension of the municipal facilities or the creation of any public improvements. 
    Minor subdivision means any subdivision containing not more than three (3) lots fronting on an existing street, not involving a new street or the extension of municipal facilities or the creation of public improvements and not adversely affecting the remainder of the parcel or adjoining property, and not in conflict with any provision of the master plan, appendix A, the official zoning map, or this chapter. 
    Nonresidential subdivision means a subdivision whose intended use is other than residential, such as commercial or industrial. Such subdivision shall comply with the applicable provisions of this chapter. 
    Owner means any person having legal title to or sufficient proprietary interest in the land sought to be subdivided under this chapter. 
    Preliminary plat means the map of a proposed subdivision and specified supporting materials, drawn and submitted in accordance with the requirements of this chapter, to permit the evaluation of the proposal prior to detailed engineering and design. 
    Public improvement means any drainage ditch, roadway, parkway, sidewalk, pedestrianway, tree, lawn, off-street parking area, lot improvement, or other facility for which the city may ultimately assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation, or which may affect an improvement for which municipal responsibility is established. 
    Replat means the platting of a previously platted subdivision where lot lines are adjusted but where easements and public dedicated property lines remain unaltered. 
    Resubdivision means a change in a map of an approved or recorded subdivision plat if such change affects any street layout on such map or area reserved thereon for public use, or any lot line; or if it affects any map or plan legally recorded prior to the adoption of any regulations controlling subdivisions. 
    Right-of-way means land set aside for use as a street, alley, or space for utility lines. 
    Sale or lease means any immediate or future transfer of ownership, or any possessory interest in land, including contract of sale, lease devise, or transfer, or an interest in a subdivision or part thereof, whether by metes and bounds, deed, contract, plat, map, lease, devise, or other written instrument. 
    Setback means the distance between any property line and the wall or support of structure. 
    Sketch plat means a sketch preparatory to the preparation of the preliminary plat, or final plat in the case of minor subdivision, to enable the subdivider to save time and expense in reaching general agreement with the planning commission as to the form of the plat and the objectives of this chapter. 
    Street means any public or private right-of-way used for or intended to be used for passage or travel by motor vehicles and affording a principal means of access to abutting property. The term "street" shall include such terms as "highway," "road," "avenue," "boulevard," "lane," "place," and similar terms. 
    Street, arterial means a limited access street of great continuity, existing or planned, which serves as a principal trafficway carrying traffic volumes from one (1) side of the city to the other. 
    Street, collector means a street carrying traffic from local streets to arterial streets within the community. 
    Street, local means a street of very limited continuity which serves or is intended to serve a small number of dwelling units. 
    Subdivider means any person, group or corporation acting as a unit, or any agent thereof dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision. 
    Subdivision means the division of a lot, tract, or parcel of land into two (2) or more lots, plats, sites or other divisions of land for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale or building development. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, §§ 24A-12, 24A-13, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-2. - Title of chapter. 
    This chapter shall be known, cited and referred to as the subdivision ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-1, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-3. - Purpose of chapter. 
    This chapter is adopted for the following purposes: 
(1)  To protect and provide for the public health, safety, and general welfare of the city. 
(2)  To guide the future growth and development of the city, in accordance with the master plan. 
(3)  To protect the character and the social and economic stability of all parts of the city and to encourage the orderly and beneficial development of all parts of the city. 
(4)  To ensure that public facilities are available and will have sufficient capacity to serve the proposed subdivision. 
(5)  To establish reasonable standards of design and procedures for subdivision and resubdivision in order to further the orderly layout and use of land; and to ensure proper legal descriptions of subdivided land. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-2, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-4. - Policy. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to consider the subdivision of land and the subsequent development of the subdivided plat as subject to the control of the city pursuant to the official master plan of the city for the orderly, planned, efficient and economical development of the city. 
(b)  Land to be subdivided shall be of such character that it can be used safely for building purposes without danger to health or peril from fire, flood or other menace, and land shall not be subdivided until available public facilities and improvements exist and proper provision has been made for drainage, water, sewer and capital improvements such as recreational facilities, transportation facilities, and improvements. 
(c)  The existing and proposed public improvements shall conform to the master plan, the zoning ordinance and the official map of the city, and it is intended that this chapter shall supplement and facilitate the enforcement of the provisions and standards contained in the Uniform Building Code, the zoning ordinance, and the official map and master plan of the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-3, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-5. - Authority for chapter. 
    This chapter is authorized by article 8, section 8-3(b) of the charter, and is hereby declared to be in accordance with all provisions of the charter. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-4, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-6. - Scope and jurisdiction of chapter. 
    This chapter shall apply to all subdivisions of land located within the corporate limits of the city, and shall also extend to and cover any major street plan adopted by the city council and applicable under state statute beyond the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-5, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-7. - Interpretation of chapter; conflicting provisions. 
(a)  Interpretation of chapter. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
(b)  Conflict with public and private provisions. 
(1)  Public provisions. This chapter is not intended to interfere with, abrogate or annul any other ordinance, rule or regulation, statute, or other provision of law, and whichever provision is more restrictive or imposes a higher standard shall control. 
(2)  Private provisions. This chapter is not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant or any other private agreement or restriction, provided that where a provision of this chapter is more restrictive or imposes a higher standard or regulation than such easement, covenant or other private agreement or restriction, the requirements of this chapter shall govern. Where the provisions of the easement, covenant or private agreement or restriction impose duties and obligations more restrictive, or higher standards than the requirements of this chapter, or the determinations of the planning commission or the council in approving a subdivision or in enforcing this chapter or determinations thereunder, then such private provisions shall be operative and supplemental to this chapter and determinations made thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-6, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-8. - Saving provision. 
    This chapter shall not be construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of prior existing subdivision regulations, or as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accruing or about to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the city under any section or provision existing at the time of adoption of this chapter, or as vacating or annulling any rights obtained by any person by lawful action of the city, except as expressly provided for in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-7, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-9. - Compliance with conditions of planning commission. 
    Regulation of the subdivision of land and the attachment of reasonable conditions to land subdivision is an exercise of valid police power delegated by the state constitution to the city. The developer has the duty of compliance with reasonable conditions laid down by the planning commission for design, dedication, improvement and restrictive use of the land so as to conform to the physical and economical development of the municipality and to the safety and general welfare of the future plot owners in the subdivision and of the community at large. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-8, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-10. - Enforcement of chapter. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the director of public works or his designee to enforce this chapter and to bring to the attention of the city attorney any violations or lack of compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  No owner or agent of the owner of any parcel of land located in a proposed subdivision shall transfer or sell any such a parcel before a plat of such subdivision has been approved by the planning commission in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and filed with the county clerk and recorder. 
(c)  The subdivision of any lot or any parcel of land by the use of metes and bounds description for the purpose of sale, transfer or lease with the intent of evading this chapter shall not be permitted. All such described subdivisions shall be subject to all the requirements contained in this chapter. 
(d)  No building permit shall be issued for the construction of any building or structure located on a lot or plat subdivided or sold in violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-11, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-11. - Variances. 
    No variances to this chapter shall be granted by city staff, the city planning commission, the city board of adjustment or the city council. However, when strict compliance with this chapter or the purposes of this chapter may prevent substantial justice from being done and may prevent the public interest from being better promoted, minor deviations from strict compliance shall be noted by staff and shall be made known by staff to the planning commission and to the city council, as part of city staff presentations, at appropriate times for consideration by both bodies, prior to approval of preliminary and final subdivision plats. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-9, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-12. - Fees. 
    Any application for subdivision, replat, subdivision variance, or any other application within the scope of this chapter shall be accompanied by a fee. The amount of the fee shall be set by the city council upon the recommendation of the public works department and shall bear a reasonable relationship to the costs involved. A schedule of fees may be found in the public works department. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-10, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Secs. 18-13-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - APPLICATION AND APPROVAL PROCEDURE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-31. - Conference with administrative staff. 
    Prior to preparing a subdivision plat, the applicant shall consult with the public works director or his designee in order to familiarize himself with the procedure for adoption of a subdivision plat and the requirements as to general layout of streets, reservations of land, street improvements, drainage, sewerage, fire protection, and the availability of existing services. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-14(a), 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-32. - Replatting. 
    A replatting may be allowed if a determination can be made by city administration that the request is confined to the following: 
(1)  Lot lines may be revised from those shown on the recorded plat provided that: 
a.  No lot or parcel of land shall be created that is less than the minimum requirements for the area or dimensions as established by this chapter or the zoning ordinance of the city; 
b.  No increase in density of the approved final plat is proposed; 
c.  No changes in easements used for drainage are proposed unless accompanied by complete engineering data; 
d.  Street locations and street rights-of-way are not to be changed; 
e.  No changes in use within the platted area are proposed; and 
f.  The plat shall not be altered in any way which will adversely affect the character of the recorded final plat. 
(2)  A replat proposal shall be approved on an administrative basis. 
a.  The applicant shall file a plat with the public works department for approval. 
b.  Administrative staff members shall study the replat, taking into consideration the requirements of this chapter. Staff members may advise the applicant of specific changes or additions, if any, required as a prerequisite to the approval of the plat. 
(c)  The director of public works or his designee shall render approval or disapproval within seven (7) days of receiving the plat, unless the director of public works determines that the replat should be referred to the planning commission. 
(3)  All other changes to a recorded plat shall be considered a subdivision and shall comply with the regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-14(b), 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89; Ord. No. 14-1999, 7-27-99, eff. 8-6-99) 
Sec. 18-33. - General procedure. 
    Whenever any subdivision of land is proposed, before any contract is made for the sale of any part thereof, and before any building permit for a structure in such proposed subdivision shall be issued, the subdividing owner or his authorized representative shall apply for and secure approval of such proposed subdivision in accordance with the following procedure: 
(1)  Minor subdivision (containing not more than three (3) lots): 
a.  Sketch plat. 
b.  Final subdivision plat. 
(2)  Major subdivision (containing four (4) or more lots): 
a.  Sketch plat. 
b.  Preliminary subdivision plat. 
c.  Final subdivision plat. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-14(c), 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-34. - Official submission date. 
    For both major and minor subdivisions, the date of the regular meeting of the planning commission at which the public hearing on final approval of the subdivision plat, including any adjourned date thereof, is closed, shall constitute the official submittal date of the plat at which the statutory period required for formal approval or disapproval of the plat shall commence to run. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-14(d), 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-35. - Submission and approval of sketch plat. 
(a)  Application procedure and requirements. Prior to subdividing land, the applicant shall file an application with the public works department for approval of a sketch plat. The application shall: 
(1)  Be made on forms available in the public works department. 
(2)  Include all contiguous holdings of the owner with an indication of the portion which is proposed to be subdivided, accompanied by an affidavit of ownership which shall include the dates the respective holdings of land were acquired, together with the book and page of each conveyance to the present owner as recorded in the office of the county clerk and recorder. 
(3)  Be accompanied by a minimum of five (5) copies of the sketch plat as described in this chapter and complying in all respects with this chapter. 
(4)  Be accompanied by a fee as determined by the city council. 
(5)  Include an address and telephone number of an agent within the territory of the municipality which shall be authorized to receive all notices required by this chapter. 
(b)  Approval. Administrative staff members shall study the sketch plat, taking into consideration the requirements of this chapter and the best use of the land being subdivided. Staff members may advise the applicant of specific changes or additions, if any, required as a prerequisite to the approval of the sketch plat. Approval of the sketch plat shall constitute authorization to the applicant to prepare and submit a preliminary plat in the case of a major subdivision and a final subdivision plat in the case of a minor subdivision. Such approval or disapproval shall be rendered by the director of public works or his designee within seven (7) days of receiving the sketch plat. The planning commission may require additional changes as a result of further study of the subdivision and preliminary or final subdivision plats. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-15, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-36. - Submission and approval of preliminary plat. 
(a)  Application procedure and requirements. Based upon the approval of the sketch plat, the applicant shall prepare, or cause to be prepared, a preliminary plat incorporating the requirements agreed upon in the sketch plat phase. 
(1)  Submission by applicant. 
a.  At least fourteen (14) days prior to a regular meeting of the planning commission, ten (10) copies of the proposed subdivision plat shall be submitted by the applicant to the public works department. 
b.  The applicant shall provide one (1) copy of the preliminary plat to the superintendent of schools and to each of the utility companies. 
c.  The applicant shall provide stamped envelopes addressed to each of the adjacent property owners within three hundred (300) feet as indicated by the clerk and recorder's office. 
(2)  Administrative staff review. Administrative staff shall review the preliminary plat and provide comments to the planning commission prior to the public hearing. 
(3)  Public hearing. The planning commission shall hold a public hearing on the preliminary plat. Such hearing shall be advertised in the same manner as the subsequent public hearing on the final subdivision plat. 
(b)  Preliminary approval. After the planning commission has reviewed the preliminary plat and administrative staff comments and testimony submitted at the public hearing is heard, the applicant shall be advised of any required changes or additions. The planning commission shall approve, conditionally approve, or disapprove the preliminary plat within fourteen (14) days after the date of the regular meeting of the planning commission at which the public hearing on the preliminary plat is held. If conditionally approved subject to modifications, the nature of the required modifications shall be indicated. One (1) copy of the preliminary plat shall be returned to the applicant with the date of approval, conditional approval or disapproval. Approval of the preliminary plat is an authorization to the subdivider to proceed with the development of the final subdivision plat. 
(c)  Public improvements. In accordance with article III of this chapter, the planning commission shall require the applicant to indicate on the plat all roads and public improvements to be dedicated; all improvements which shall be required to be established for water, fire and utilities; and any other special requirements deemed necessary by the planning commission in order to have the subdivision plat conform to the master plan of the city. 
(d)  Effective period of preliminary approval. The approval of a preliminary plat shall be effective for a period of one (1) year, at the end of which time final approval on the subdivision must have been obtained from the planning commission. Any plat not receiving final approval within the period of time set forth in this subsection shall be null and void, and the developer shall be required to resubmit a plat for preliminary approval subject to all new zoning restrictions and subdivision regulations, if applicable. 
(e)  Zoning regulations. Every plat shall conform to existing zoning regulations and subdivision regulations applicable at the time of proposed final approval, except that any plat which has received preliminary approval shall be exempt from any subsequent amendments to the zoning ordinance rendering the plat nonconforming as to bulk or use, provided that final approval is obtained within the one-year period. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-16, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89) 
Sec. 18-37. - Submission and approval of final subdivision plat. 
(a)  Application procedures and requirements. Following the approval of the sketch plat in the case of a minor subdivision, or of the preliminary plat in the case of a major subdivision, the applicant shall prepare or cause to be prepared a final subdivision plat incorporating the requirements agreed upon in the sketch plat and preliminary plat phases. 
(1)  Submission by applicant. 
a.  At least fourteen (14) days prior to a regular meeting of the planning commission, ten (10) copies of the proposed final subdivision plat shall be submitted by the applicant to the public works department. 
b.  The applicant shall provide all formal irrevocable offers of dedication to the public of all streets, utilities, parks and easements, in a form approved by the city attorney. The final subdivision plat shall be marked with a notation indicating the formal offers of dedication as follows: 
The owner(s) hereby irrevocably offer(s) for dedication to the City of Sterling all the streets, easements, parks and required utilities shown in the Subdivision Plat in accordance with the irrevocable offer of dedication dated ____________ / ____________ / ____________ and recorded in the County Clerk and Recorder's Office. 
By: _____
Owner Date: _____  
c.  The applicant shall provide stamped envelopes addressed to each adjacent property owner within three hundred (300) feet as indicated in the county clerk and recorder's office. 
d.  The applicant shall submit a performance bond for the benefit of the city for the performance of all required subdivision public and lot improvements and for all improvements and land included in the irrevocable offer of dedication for the dedication to the city free and clear of all liens and encumbrances. The amount of the performance bond shall be one hundred fifteen (115) percent of an estimate of all costs for all street, water, sanitary and other improvements, including lot improvements on individual lots as required in this chapter, specified in the final subdivision plat, and as approved by the planning commission and the city council, such estimate as provided by the applicant's certified engineer and approved by the director of public works. The performance bond required shall be in such form as is satisfactory to the city attorney. 
In addition to the performance bond requirements as specified by this subsection d, the applicant shall also submit to the city, after certification of completion by the public works director, a subdivision bond to guarantee that any defects in the improvements within the subdivision shall be corrected at the applicant's expense, for a period of three (3) years from the date of certification. The subdivision bond required shall be in such form as is satisfactory to the city attorney. At the direction of the city council, the city administration may impose liquidated damages to be paid daily and set at an amount determined by the city council at the time of subdivision approval, and not to exceed a period of ninety (90) days prior to the expiration of the time period set by the city council to construct all improvements. 
e.  The applicant shall submit construction plans as outlined in this chapter. 
(2)  Notice of public hearing. Upon receipt of the final subdivision plat and all supporting material, the chairperson of the planning commission shall call a public hearing for the next scheduled meeting of the planning commission to be held at least fourteen (14) days after the date of submission. The secretary of the planning commission will submit a notice for publication in one (1) newspaper of general circulation to be published at least seven (7) days prior to the public hearing and mail notices to all property owners as specified in subsection (a)(1)c. of this section, and shall maintain file copies of the plat for public review prior to the hearing. 
(b)  Public hearing and determination. 
(1)  At the public hearing, the planning commission shall give an opportunity to any interested persons to examine or comment on the plat. After the public hearing, the planning commission shall, within fourteen (14) days after closing of the public hearing, recommend to the city council approval, conditional approval, or disapproval of the subdivision application, which shall set forth in detail any conditions to which the approval is subject, or reasons for disapproval. 
(2)  One (1) copy of the final subdivision plat shall be returned to the subdivider with the date of approval, conditional approval, or disapproval noted thereon, and the reasons therefor accompanying the plat. 
(Ord. No. 10-1989, § 24A-17, 8-22-89, eff. 9-4-89; Ord. No. 2-1990, § 24A-17, 4-13-90, eff. 4-23-90; Ord. No. 52-1997, 9-23-97, eff. 10-3-97) 
Sec. 18-38. - Site specific development plans; vested rights. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Site specific development plan means those developments for which the landowner desires the creation of a vested property right, the approval by the city council of the project at a public hearing, which hearing shall be specifically requested by the landowner, and which public hearing shall be either: 
a.  Conducted immediately following at the same city council meeting as the approval of the final plat; or, 
b.  If no final plat approval is required, conducted following the successful approval of the development at all other required stages of the development review process. 
Failure of the landowner to request such a public hearing renders the approval not a site specific development plan, and no vested rights shall be deemed to have been created. 
(2)  Vested property right means the right to undertake and complete the development and use of property under the terms and conditions of a site specific development plan. 
(b)  Notice and hearing. No site specific development plan shall be approved until after a public hearing, preceded by written notice of such hearing. Such notice may, at the city's option, be combined with the notice required by C.R.S. 31-23-304 for zoning regulations, or with any other required notice. At such public hearing interested persons shall have an opportunity to be heard. 
(c)  Effective date; amendments. A site specific development plan shall be deemed approved upon the effective date of the city council approval action relating thereto as set forth in subsection (b) of this section. If amendments to a site specific development plan are proposed and approved, the effective date of such amendments, for purposes of duration of a vested property right, shall be the date of the approval of the original site specific development plan, unless the city council specifically finds to the contrary and incorporates such finding in its approval of the amendment. 
(d)  Required language; notice of approval. Each map, plat, or site plan or other document constituting a site specific development plan shall contain the following language: "Approval of this plan may create a vested property right pursuant to article 68 of title 24, C.R.S., as amended." Failure to contain this statement shall invalidate the creation of the vested property right. In addition, a notice describing generally the type and intensity of use approved, the specific parcels of property affected and stating that a vested property right has been created shall be published once, not more than fourteen (14) days after approval of the site specific development plan, in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. 
(e)  Payment of costs. In addition to any and all other fees and charges imposed by this Code, the applicant for approval of a site specific develop ment plan shall pay all costs occasioned to the finance director as a result of the site specific development plan review, including publication of notices, public hearing and review costs. Such costs or fees relative thereto shall be as determined and set by the city council. 
(f)  Approval not to affect other requirements. Approval of a site specific development plan shall not constitute an exemption from or waiver of any other provisions of this Code pertaining to the development and use of property. 
(g)  Limitations. Nothing in this section is intended to create any vested property right, but only to implement the provisions of C.R.S. title 24, article 68.
