ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 20-1-20-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAILER PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Trailer coach means any vehicle, other than a railroad car, used for living or sleeping purposes, which is equipped with wheels for the purpose of transporting such vehicle from place to place, either by its own power or by some other attached to it. 
    Trailer coach lot means any unit of land provided by any person for the purpose of placing thereon a trailer coach which is used or intended to be used for living or sleeping purposes. 
    Trailer park means any premises where one (1) or more trailer coaches are parked for living or sleeping purposes, or any premises used or set apart for the purpose of supplying to the public a parking space for one (1) or more trailer coaches for living or sleeping purposes, including any building, structure, vehicle and enclosure used or intended for use as a part of the equipment of such trailer park. 
(Code 1961, § 25-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2; flood prevention and protection, Ch. 8; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 17; subdivisions, Ch. 18; utilities, Ch. 21; zoning, App. A. 
Sec. 20-27. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of public works, with the assistance of the police, fire and health departments, to cause regular semiannual inspections to be made of each trailer park in the city. 
(Code 1961, § 25-13) 
Sec. 20-28. - Responsibility for maintenance of facilities. 
    Owners, operators and attendants of trailer parks shall be responsible for maintaining the safety and sanitary facilities required by this article. 
(Code 1961, § 25-39) 
Sec. 20-29. - Attendants. 
    The owner or operator of any trailer park shall have one (1) or more attendants present on the premises at all reasonable times to manage and supervise the park and to enforce or cause compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1961, § 25-14) 
Sec. 20-30. - Registration of guests. 
(a)  Each person occupying or purporting to occupy a trailer coach on any trailer coach lot in any trailer park shall be required to give the following information in writing: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner and occupants of the trailer. 
(2)  The license number, make and model of the tow car and the trailer coach. 
(3)  The location at which the trailer coach was last parked, the date of moving from such place, and the place to which the occupants are moving. 
(b)  All such registrations shall be signed by the occupant of the trailer coach on the date of arrival, and such date and the date of departure shall be filled in by the operator of the trailer park. 
(c)  Any person furnishing false information in connection with such registration shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the trailer park operator to furnish registration forms and make them readily available for inspection by properly constituted authorities. 
(Code 1961, § 25-43) 
Sec. 20-31. - Ejection of certain persons. 
    The owner, operator or attendant of a trailer park shall eject any person willfully damaging any facility required by this article or refusing to comply with provisions of this article. 
(Code 1961, § 24-40) 
Sec. 20-32. - Report of contagious diseases. 
    It shall be the duty of every owner, operator or attendant of a trailer park to report promptly to the health department the full name, age and address of every person who is affected or suspected of being affected with any contagious or communicable diseases. 
(Code 1961, § 25-38) 
Sec. 20-33. - Compliance with building code, zoning ordinance. 
    All buildings and structures at trailer parks other than trailer coaches shall be in full conformity with the building code and in accordance with the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1961, § 25-41) 
Sec. 20-34. - Removal of wheels from trailers; placement of foundations. 
    The removal of the wheels from any house trailer located at a trailer park is hereby prohibited, except temporarily for the purpose of repairs. Posts, piers, foundations and any other thing that will prevent the ready removal of the trailer from the premises are also prohibited. The owner, operator or attendant of the trailer park shall be responsible for the enforcement of this section. 
(Code 1961, § 25-42) 
Secs. 20-35-20-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and business regulations, Ch. 9. 

Sec. 20-51. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, operate or offer to operate a trailer park within the corporate limits of the city without first securing a written trailer park permit from the director of public works. 
(Code 1961, § 25-2) 
Sec. 20-52. - Application generally. 
    Application for a permit required by this division shall be made in writing upon forms provided by the building inspector, shall be accompanied by payment of an investigation fee of five dollars ($5.00), and shall state the name and address of the applicant and a description of the property. 
(Code 1961, § 25-3) 
Sec. 20-53. - Submission of plans. 
    Each application for a permit required by this division shall be accompanied by a plan of the proposed trailer park drawn to scale and showing, in addition to such detailed information as may be required by the director of public works, the following: 
(1)  That the park is located on a well-drained site, has a well-marked entrance and exit, has surfaced roads of not less than twenty-five (25) feet in width, adequately lighted at night and easily accessible to all trailer coaches and fire apparatus, and has surfaced walkways to the various buildings of such park. 
(2)  That a trailer coach lot having an area of not less than nine hundred (900) square feet and a minimum width of twenty (20) feet, with boundaries clearly indicated by corner markers, is provided for each trailer coach. 
(3)  That coach lots are to be arranged in rows, each abutting or facing upon one (1) or more public or private roads, and that each trailer coach or tow car is to be located at least two (2) feet from the boundary line of each lot. 
(4)  That space is provided as follows: 
a.  For clothes drying and laundry facilities, not less than one hundred (100) square feet. 
b.  For burning and incineration of rubbish, not less than twenty-five (25) feet from the nearest coach lot line. 
c.  An adequate play area for children, set aside and used for no other purpose. 
(5)  The extent and conformation of the premises. 
(6)  The location of driveways, entrances, exits and the like. 
(7)  The number and location of coach lots. 
(8)  The number and location of all structures and conveniences. 
(9)  The method of sewage disposal. 
(10)  The method of garbage storage and removal. 
(11)  The plan of the water supply system. 
(12)  The plan of the electric wiring system. 
(13)  The location of the incinerator and burning space. 
(14)  The location of children's play and recreation areas. 
(Code 1961, § 25-4) 
Sec. 20-54. - Investigation of applicant and proposed site. 
    When an application for a permit required by this division has been filed, the director of public works, with the assistance of the fire, police and health departments, shall cause an investigation to be made of the character and fitness of the applicant and the conformity of the site of the proposed trailer park with the requirements of this article, section 20-51, and the rules and regulations of the fire and health departments. 
(Code 1961, § 25-5) 
Sec. 20-55. - Standards for issuance. 
    No permit required by this division shall be issued unless the proposed site for the trailer park complies with all requirements of this article and the rules and regulations of the fire and health departments, nor shall such permit be issued if the applicant therefor has ever been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude. 
(Code 1961, § 25-6) 
Sec. 20-56. - Display. 
    A trailer park permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be conspicuously displayed on the premises used or proposed to be used as a trailer park. 
(Code 1961, § 25-7) 
Secs. 20-57-20-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and business regulations, Ch. 9. 

Sec. 20-76. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain a trailer park within the city without first securing a license therefor. Such license is in addition to the permit required by this article. 
(Code 1961, § 25-8) 
Sec. 20-77. - Fee. 
    For each trailer park license issued there shall be paid to the director of finance an annual fee based upon the number of trailer coach lots permitted for such trailer park. The minimum fee shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) for the first ten (10) or less trailer coach lots and one dollar ($1.00) for each additional trailer coach lot in excess of ten (10). 
(Code 1961, § 25-9) 
Sec. 20-78. - Term; renewal. 
    A license for a trailer park shall be valid for the calendar year in which issued. Such license shall be renewable upon written application therefor prior to December 31 of any year and upon payment of the fee prescribed in this division. 
(Code 1961, § 25-10) 
Sec. 20-79. - Transfer. 
    A trailer park license may be transferred upon application therefor being made to the director of finance and approved by the director of public works, after investigation, and upon payment of a transfer fee of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Code 1961, § 25-11) 
Sec. 20-80. - Suspension; revocation. 
(a)  When it appears to the director of public works, the chief of the fire department, the chief of the police department or the health department that any person holding a license under this division has or may have violated any of the provisions of this division or any health regulation of the city, a written notice shall be served on such licensee in person or by registered mail specifying wherein it is believed he violated or may have violated this division or any health regulation and requiring him to appear before the city manager at a time specified therein not less than ten (10) days after such service and show cause why such license should not be suspended or revoked. At such time, the licensee and the health, fire, police and building officials of the city may produce such evidence as may be relevant to determine whether the violation contained in the charge has been committed. If the city manager finds that such violation has not been committed, he shall so advise the licensee and the licensee shall be permitted to continue operation, but if the city manager finds from the evidence that such violation has been committed he shall so advise the licensee and may suspend or revoke the license. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person whose license has been revoked or suspended to operate, continue to operate or offer to operate any trailer park after the date of such revocation or during the term of such suspension, as the case may be. 
(Code 1961, § 25-12) 
Secs. 20-81-20-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SAFETY AND SANITATION REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 20-96. - Entrance and exit signs. 
    Each trailer park in the city shall be equipped with lighted entrance and exit signs. 
(Code 1961, § 25-15) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10. 
Sec. 20-97. - Storage of liquid fuel. 
    Storage tanks for liquid fuel at a trailer park shall be located so as to require filling or draining on the outside of the trailer coach. Tanks for liquefied petroleum gases shall be located outside of the trailer coach. If tanks are installed in closed compartments, the compartments shall be ventilated at the bottom. 
(Code 1961, § 25-16) 
Sec. 20-98. - Incinerator. 
    No incinerator shall be used at any trailer park unless the incinerator has been approved by the fire department. 
(Code 1961, § 25-17) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 20-99. - Rubbish containers. 
    There shall be provided at each trailer park a sufficient number of rubbish containers placed at such locations as may be designated by the director of public works. Such containers shall be of metal and shall be equipped with metal self-closing tops. 
(Code 1961, § 25-18) 
Sec. 20-100. - Open fires prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to light or maintain or allow to be lit or maintained any open fire in a trailer park. 
(Code 1961, § 25-19) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 20-101. - Fire alarm box or telephone facilities. 
    Each trailer park shall have available at all times a fire alarm box or public telephone facilities. 
(Code 1961, § 25-20) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 20-102. - Fire extinguishers. 
    Each trailer park shall be equipped with such number of fire extinguishers as may be required by the fire department. Each trailer coach located in a trailer park shall be equipped with at least one (1) fire extinguisher suitable for suppressing oil and gasoline fires. 
(Code 1961, § 25-21) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 20-103. - Parking in driveways and walkways. 
    No tow car, trailer or other vehicle shall be parked in any driveway or over any walkway in a trailer park. 
(Code 1961, § 25-22) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10. 
Sec. 20-104. - Electrical equipment and lighting. 
    Each trailer park located in the city shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Each lot must have an electric outlet in weatherproof housing with a fuse or circuit breaker not to exceed twenty (20) amps for each circuit. Overhead feeder wires shall be a minimum of twelve (12) feet from the ground and outlet boxes shall be at least six (6) feet from the ground on substantial poles placed on the lot line. 
(2)  Utility and toilet buildings shall be adequately lighted, with a sixty-watt bulb over each entrance. 
(3)  Outside lighting shall consist of at least one (1) twenty-five-watt light at fifteen (15) feet for every one hundred (100) feet on driveways and walkways. 
(4)  All park lights shall burn from one-half hour after sundown to one-half hour before sunrise. 
(5)  All wiring shall comply with the state electrical code. 
(Code 1961, § 25-23) 
Sec. 20-105. - Water supply. 
    The city water supply shall be made available at each trailer park, and each such park shall have at least one (1) water outlet within one hundred (100) feet of each lot. No physical connection shall be made between the approved water supply and any unsafe water supply. 
(Code 1961, § 25-24) 
Sec. 20-106. - Use of common drinking cups prohibited. 
    The use of common drinking cups at trailer parks is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1961, § 25-25) 
Sec. 20-107. - Plumbing generally. 
    All plumbing in every trailer park shall comply with the city building code and state plumbing code and all ordinances pertaining to plumbing and to the disposal of sewage. 
(Code 1961, § 25-26) 
Sec. 20-108. - Toilet facilities. 
(a)  Separate toilet facilities for males and females shall be provided at every trailer park. 
(b)  One (1) water closet for males and one (1) for females shall be provided for each fifteen (15) trailers or less and at least one (1) urinal shall be provided in each toilet room for males. Only approved water-flush urinals and toilets shall be used and each water closet shall be located in a separate compartment at least three (3) feet wide. 
(c)  Trailer coaches equipped with toilet facilities shall not be considered in computing the number of water closets required by this section. 
(Code 1961, § 25-27) 
Sec. 20-109. - Laundry facilities. 
    Each trailer park shall have a laundry building or room with hot and cold running water and at least one (1) double laundry tray for every thirty (30) trailer lots. No laundry tray shall be located in a toilet or shower room. 
(Code 1961, § 25-28) 
Sec. 20-110. - Showers. 
    Each trailer park shall provide separate shower bath accommodations for males and females with an adequate supply of hot and cold running water at all reasonable hours. There shall be a minimum of one (1) approved shower head and stall for every twenty (20) persons or major fraction thereof. A dressing compartment at least two and one-half (21/2) by three (3) feet in size shall be provided in combination with each shower stall, protected by a waterproof partition or shower curtain. The floor of such compartment shall be waterproof and elevated three (3) inches above the shower stall floor. 
(Code 1961, § 25-29) 
Sec. 20-111. - Lavatories. 
    Each trailer park shall be equipped with one (1) lavatory for every two (2) water closets for females and two (2) lavatories for every three (3) water closets for males. 
(Code 1961, § 25-30) 
Sec. 20-112. - Construction, cleaning of buildings housing sanitary facilities. 
(a)  Sanitary facilities at a trailer park shall be located in a well-constructed and properly lighted and drained building, with a cement floor or the equivalent. Such facilities shall not be located in a basement in which more than half the height of the basement is below ground level. Such buildings shall have concrete curbings extending at least six (6) inches above the floor. 
(b)  All toilet, shower, lavatory and laundry building floors shall be cleaned daily with strong soap or detergent and then rinsed down. 
(c)  All windows, doors and other openings of such buildings shall be properly screened with wire cloth screening not coarser than sixteen (16) mesh. Screen doors shall swing outward and be self-closing. 
(Code 1961, § 25-31) 
Sec. 20-113. - Lots to be located near toilet and shower facilities. 
    No trailer coach lot at a trailer park shall be located more than two hundred (200) feet in walking distance away from toilet and shower facilities. 
(Code 1961, § 25-32) 
Sec. 20-114. - Sewers. 
    All sewage and other water-carried wastes produced at a trailer park shall be disposed of through the city sanitary sewer system when possible; otherwise, they shall be disposed of through a system approved by the health department. Each lot shall be provided with a sewer trapped below the frost line and there shall be a watertight connection from the trailer coach sewer outlet to the sewer line and all trailer coaches shall be connected. The sewer line shall be tightly closed when not in use. 
(Code 1961, § 25-33) 
Cross reference- Sewer system, § 21-116 et seq. 
Sec. 20-115. - Place for cleaning garbage cans. 
    Each trailer park shall have an accessible place for cleaning slop and garbage cans and water under pressure shall be provided at such place. Such a place shall be located within two hundred (200) feet of each trailer lot. 
(Code 1961, § 25-34) 
Sec. 20-116. - Community kitchens and dining rooms. 
    Community kitchens or dining rooms located at trailer parks shall be maintained and operated in accordance with applicable provisions of this Code and other city ordinances. 
(Code 1961, § 25-35) 
Sec. 20-117. - Slop-creating practices to be limited to designated areas. 
    No animal or car washing or other slop-creating practices shall be carried on in any place at a trailer park not designed for such purposes. 
(Code 1961, § 25-36) 
Sec. 20-118. - Animals not to run at large. 
    No person shall allow any domestic animal or house pet to run at large within limits of a trailer park. 
(Code 1961, § 25-36) 
Chapter 21 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Department of public works, §§ 4-6, 8-1; public works board, § 8-4; public utilities, § 14-1 et seq.; franchises, § 14-1 et seq.; municipal utilities, § 14-9 et seq. 
Cross reference- Standards for areas of special flood hazards regarding utilities, § 8-66(3); specific standards in all areas of special flood hazards where base flood elevation data has been provided, § 8-67; public improvements, planning, construction, assessments and collection procedures, Ch. 15; excavations for utilities in streets, sidewalks and other public places, § 17-41 et seq.; drainage and storm sewer specification and design requirements in subdivisions, § 18-103; occupation tax on telephone utility companies, § 19-76 et seq.; finance, § 19-181 et seq.; trailer park regulations, § 20-26 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 21-1-21-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - APPLICATION FOR SERVICE; BILLING AND COLLECTION OF CHARGES FOR SERVICES 

Sec. 21-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Customer means a person who is either a legal owner of real property or such legal owner's authorized agent for which utility services are furnished. 
    Utility charges means all charges applicable to water, sewer and sanitation collection services and all charges applicable to such other city services as are designated by this Code as utility charges. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-3, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-27. - Purpose of article. 
    The city council finds and declares that the provisions of this article are enacted for the following reasons: 
(1)  To ensure timely and complete payment of all utility charges arising from utility services supplied to city customers and arising from charges assessed under this article. 
(2)  To regulate termination of utility services to customers for nonpayment of utility charges. 
(3)  To provide full and adequate notice to a customer of a termination of utility service to that customer and of the procedure to follow to avoid termination. 
(4)  To provide customers with a fair and reasonable opportunity, prior to termination, to dispute the correctness of utility charges. 
(5)  To standardize the contents of the utility bill, the notice of termination and other notices sent to customers. 
(6)  To regulate termination of utility services to customers for nonpayment of utility charges during inclement weather. 
(7)  To require utility services furnished to specific real property to be in the name of the legal or equitable titled owner of that specific real property. 
(8)  To provide customers [with] adequate notice of termination of utility services. 
(9)  To provide for liens for utility charges, notice of lien filing and certification of lien for collection as other taxes. 
(10)  To enforce by penalties the requirements of persons receiving or requesting city utility services. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-1, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Sec. 21-28. - Applicability of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to utility services supplied to customers' real properties as utility charges against real properties. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-2, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 21-29. - Additional rules and regulations. 
    The finance director or his designee is authorized to develop all written rules and regulations necessary to implement the provisions of this article, subject to the approval of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-15, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 21-30. - Service application and agreement-Required. 
    Any person who is a legal owner of real property to which the city may agree to provide utilities and who desires utility services at the specific real property shall complete and submit to the city a utility service application and agreement, together with an application fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00), which fee amount may be changed by resolution from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, §§ 25C-3(a)(3), 25C-5(a), 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95; Ord. No. 3-2008, 2-26-08, eff. 3-7-08) 
Sec. 21-31. - Service application and agreement-Contents. 
    The utility service application and agreement shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and signature of the applicant, who is the legal owner. 
(2)  The street address and the legal description of the property to be supplied utility services. 
(3)  The legal owner's telephone number and address to which utility billings and notices are to be mailed, if the address is different from the address to which utility services are requested to be furnished; 
(4)  The number on the legal owner's driver's license or valid government issued identification card, containing a photograph of the applicant; 
(5)  The name, address and telephone number of the person to whom utility billings are being mailed, if the name is different from the applicant; 
(6)  The utility services that are being requested, whether water, sewer, sanitation collection or other services; 
(7)  A statement that full and complete payment of a utility bill must be made no later than the payment date stated on the monthly utility bill, which payment date shall be at least twenty (20) calendar days from the date of the utility bill; 
(8)  A statement that failure to pay timely and completely by the due date the total amount stated in a utility bill shall result in: 
a.  Addition of a penalty late charge of an amount equal to ten (10) percent of the total amount of the utility bill; and/or 
b.  Termination of utility service; 
(9)  Written acknowledgment by the prospective customer that, as the customer, the customer is responsible for the timely and complete payment of all utility charges arising from utility service supplied to the property identified in the utility service application and agreement form; 
(10)  Customer shall receive a copy of this article; 
(11)  Acknowledgment that the customer understands the customer's rights in the event of receipt of a notice of rejection or notice of termination, and acknowledgment of the obligation of the customer to inform the city, in writing, of a change of the customer's billing address, a change in the service provided or requested, and other such changes affecting services provided or to be provided; and 
(12)  Acknowledgment by the prospective customer that the information supplied by the prospective customer is factual, and that if improper, less-than-accurate, false or misleading information is given by the prospective customer, the city may, upon ascertainment of the true facts, bill as utility charges for any and all amounts which should have been charged and as are proper and appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-5(b), 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95; Ord. No. 10-2009, 3-24-09, eff. 4-3-09) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction for computation of time, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-32. - Same-To be signed by person requesting service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any qualified person requesting city utility services not to sign a utility services application and agreement. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-12, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 21-33. - Same-Misrepresentation of ownership of property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not a legal owner of a specific real property, receiving or requesting city utility services for such real property, to represent upon a utility services application and agreement that such person is a legal owner of the real property receiving or requesting city utility services. Violation of this section shall be considered a violation of section 12-2 of the City Code, and shall be prosecuted as such. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-14, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Sec. 21-34. - Notice of rejection. 
    If utility services will not be supplied to the property for which requested, a notice of rejection shall be sent to the prospective customer at the billing address provided in the utility service application and agreement. Such notice shall state the specific reasons why services will not be supplied. Utility services shall not be supplied to any prospective customer if that customer has any outstanding and unpaid utility charges relative to the real property for which utility services are being requested. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-5(c), 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 5-1990, 6-12-90, eff. 6-15-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Sec. 21-35. - Billing; payment of bill; penalty charges. 
(a)  A utility bill shall be mailed monthly for utility services supplied. 
(b)  Total payment of a utility bill must be made at the city by 5:00 p.m. of the due date on the utility bill. The due date shall be at least twenty (20) calendar days from the date of the utility bill. 
(c)  Failure to pay a utility bill timely and completely shall result in a penalty late charge of an amount equal to ten (10) percent of the total amount of the utility bill added to the utility bill as a utility charge. 
(d)  Each utility bill shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The reading date of utility service covered by the utility bill; 
(2)  The utility charges, and miscellaneous charges where applicable; 
(3)  The date of the utility bill; 
(4)  The date when complete payment is due at the city, which shall be at least twenty (20) calendar days from the date of the utility bill; 
(5)  Notice whether the utility bill is based on an actual or an estimated measurement of the amount of utility service supplied; 
(6)  Notice that failure to pay, timely and completely by the due date, the total amount shown on the utility bill shall result in: 
a.  Addition of a penalty late charge of an amount equal to ten (10) percent of the total amount of the utility bill; and/or 
b.  Termination of utility service; 
(7)  Notice that the customer may call an information center telephone number during business hours which shall be listed on the utility bill, in order to: 
a.  Dispute the amount of the utility charges and/or penalty late charge; 
b.  Avoid the termination of utility service for nonpayment of the total amount shown on the utility bill; 
c.  Request the restoration of utility service; 
d.  Request answers to any other questions regarding utility services; and 
(8)  Notice that a notice of lien may be recorded by the city clerk after five (5) days following the day utility charges are due and payable. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-6, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction for computation of time, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-36. - Customer information. 
    The information center provided for in this article shall provide information on the following: 
(1)  The procedure to dispute a utility charge or a penalty late charge; 
(2)  The procedure to avoid termination of utility service due to nonpayment of utility charges or penalty late charges; 
(3)  The procedure for tenants to avoid termination of utility service due to their landlord's nonpayment of utility charges and penalties; and 
(4)  The procedure to obtain reinstatement of utility services. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-7, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 21-37. - Disputes. 
(a)  Prior to five (5) days before the date of termination of utility service for nonpayment of the amount shown on a utility bill or on a notice of termination issued under section 21-41, a customer may dispute the correctness of all or part of the amount shown in accordance with the provisions of this article. A customer shall not be entitled to dispute the correctness of all or part of the amount if all or part of the amount was the subject of a previous dispute under this section. 
(b)  The procedure for customer dispute shall be as follows: 
(1)  Prior to five (5) days before the date of termination, the customer shall notify the finance director, in writing, that the customer disputes all or part of the amount shown on the utility bill or a notice of termination, stating as completely as possible the basis for the dispute. 
(2)  If the finance director determines that the present dispute is untimely or that the customer previously disputed the correctness of all or part of the amount shown, the finance director shall mail to the customer a notice of rejection stating that the present dispute is untimely or invalid. The city shall then proceed as if the customer had not notified the city of the present dispute. 
(3)  If the city determines that the present dispute is not untimely or invalid under this section, the city, within five (5) business days after receipt of the customer's notice, shall arrange a formal hearing before the city manager or his designee (the hearing official). 
(4)  The formal hearing before the hearing official shall be held within ten (10) days of the city's receipt of the customer's written request. 
(5)  At the hearing, the city and the customer shall be entitled to present all evidence that is, in the hearing official's view, relevant and material to the dispute, and to examine and cross-examine witnesses. A tape-recorded or, at the option of the city, a stenographic record of the hearing shall be maintained. 
(6)  Based on the record established at the hearing, the hearing official, within five (5) days of completion of the hearing, shall issue a written decision formally resolving the dispute. Such decision shall be final and binding upon the city and the customer. 
(c)  Utilization of this dispute procedure shall not relieve a customer of his obligation to pay, timely and completely, all other undisputed utility charges and penalty late charges and the undisputed portion of the amount which is the subject of the present dispute. Notwithstanding subsection (d) of this section, failure to pay, timely and completely, all such undisputed amounts shall subject the customer to termination of utility service in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(d)  Until the date of the city official's decision, the city shall not terminate the utility service of the customer and shall not issue a notice of termination to the customer solely for nonpayment of the disputed amount. If it is determined that the customer must pay some or all of the disputed amount, the city shall promptly mail to the customer and the customer's known units, from information furnished by the customer, a notice of termination, which shall contain the following: 
(1)  The amount to be paid. 
(2)  The date of the notice of termination. 
(3)  The date of termination, which shall be at least ten (10) days after the date of the notice of termination. 
(4)  Notice that, unless the city receives complete payment of the amount shown prior to the date of termination, utility services shall be terminated. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-9, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 21-38. - Charges to constitute lien; authority to terminate service. 
    All utility charges shall constitute a lien upon the property benefited by utility services provided, and if such utility charges are not paid in full as billed and when due, utility services to the property may be disconnected in conformance with the provisions of this article. Once the lien has been filed with the county clerk and recorder, there will be a one-hundred-dollar service charge which will be required to be paid in addition to full payment of the bill, such service charge being for the purpose of filing expenses and labor incurred in the production of the paperwork required for such lien. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-8(a), 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Sec. 21-39. - Notice of lien. 
(a)  Notice of lien shall be prepared and filed by the city clerk with the clerk and recorder of the county after five (5) days following the day utility charges were due and not paid. 
(b)  Such notice of lien shall include the following: 
(1)  The name of the owner of the property; 
(2)  A legal description of the property as tax assessed by the county assessor, and the number and street address of the property to which the notice of lien is applicable; 
(3)  The nature of the lien; and 
(4)  A statement that notice of lien is given pursuant to this section. 
(c)  The city clerk shall mail a copy of such notice of lien to the billing address of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-8(b)-(d), 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Sec. 21-40. - Collection of lien. 
    All utility charges and assessments shall constitute a lien upon the property benefitted by services, wherever referred to in this Code as utility charges. If such utility charges are not paid in full as billed when due, the director of finance may certify the utility charges or assessments to the county treasurer, to be placed upon the tax list for the current year to be collected in the manner as other taxes are collected. All laws of the state for the assessment and collection of general taxes shall apply, including the laws for the sale of property for taxes and redemption of property. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-4, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Sec. 21-41. - Service termination procedure. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection 21-37(d), the provisions of this section shall govern all terminations of utility service for nonpayment of utility charges. 
(b)  If, by the payment due date shown on a utility bill or within ten (10) days of mailing by the city of a notice of rejection as provided in section 21-34, the city has not received complete payment of the total amount shown on the utility bill or the notice of rejection, the city shall mail to the owner a notice of termination at least three (3) days after the payment due date shown on the utility bill. 
(c)  The notice of termination shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner; 
(2)  The address of the owner which the owner has designated as the billing address; 
(3)  The names, addresses, apartment or unit numbers as furnished by the owner; 
(4)  The amount to be paid; 
(5)  The date of the notice of termination; 
(6)  The date of termination, which shall be at least ten (10) calendar days from the date of the notice of termination; 
(7)  Notice that, unless the city receives complete payment of the amount shown prior to the date of termination, utility service shall be terminated as provided for in this section; 
(8)  Notice that, in lieu of paying the entire amount shown, a customer, prior to the date of termination, may notify the city that the customer disputes the correctness of all or part of the amount shown, if all or part of the amount shown was not the subject of a previous dispute under section 21-37; and 
(9)  Notice of the information available at the office of the finance director and described in section 21-36. 
(d)  If, prior to the date of termination: 
(1)  The city has not received complete payment of the amount shown on the notice of termination; or 
(2)  The customer has not notified the city that the customer disputes the correctness of all or part of the amount shown on the notice of termination; 
then the city shall terminate utility service provided to the customer on the date of termination. 
(e)  If the city receives payment of the entire amount shown on the notice of termination prior to the date of termination, such payment shall be considered a timely and complete payment for purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-10, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Sec. 21-42. - Limitations on termination of service. 
(a)  The city shall terminate utility service for nonpayment of utility charges only during the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m., Monday through Thursday. No terminations shall be permitted on a legal holiday or on the day before a legal holiday. 
(b)  The city shall not terminate utility service for nonpayment of amounts less than twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-11, 12- 27-89, eff. 1-1-90; Ord. No. 34-1995, 12-12-95, eff. 12-22-95) 
Sec. 21-43. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 34-1995, adopted December 12, 1995, effective December 22, 1995, deleted § 21-43 in its entirety. Formerly, § 21-43 pertained to unlawful receipt of service by tenants after expiration of tenancy and derived from Ord. No. 20-1989, § 25C-13, adopted December 27, 1989, effective January 1, 1990. 
Secs. 21-44-21-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER SERVICE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Water utility, § 14-10. 
Cross reference- Water facilities requirements in subdivisions, § 18-104. 
State Law reference- Authority of cities relative to water service generally, C.R.S. 31-12-101 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City's water system includes wells, pumping stations, transmission lines, taps and other related appurtenances owned or operated by the city. 
    Private water system means any arrangement providing water from a source other than the city's water system or providing water from the city's water system without the city's permission pursuant to the requirements of this article. 
    Public water service means the providing of water from the city's water system. 
    Tap may be used interchangeably with the terms "metered tap," "water service connection," "service tap," "service" and other similar terms. These terms refer to the location or structure where water supplied by the city enters on individual private property. 
    Utility charges means and includes tapping charges, water service charges, permit fees relating to this article, restoration of water service fee, water plant investment fee, and such other fees that are set pursuant to this article, plus such other costs assessed by the city to recover the actual cost of any occurrence which violates the requirements of this article. 
    Water service means the receipt of water from the city's water system on private property. 
(Code 1961, § 26-1; Ord. No. 20-1989, § 26-1, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-62. - Applicability of article to government-owned lands. 
    In order to obtain water service, any government or governmental agency owning property located within the corporate boundaries of the city or eligible for immediate annexation shall comply with all applicable sections of this article, unless specifically prevented from doing so by state law, in which case the city may modify the requirements to the extent of the state law which is effective. Any private owner or developer who buys or receives land from any government or governmental agency, whether eligible for annexation or not, shall meet the requirements of this article before water service will be initiated or continued on the property. 
(Code 1961, § 26-13) 
Sec. 21-63. - Violation of article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this article or any of the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 7-1989, § 26-17, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89) 
Sec. 21-64. - Acquisition of water rights by city. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city that, in order to provide an orderly growth of the city and to ensure the city an adequate water supply and to provide the necessary water and water rights for the continuing expansion and water right protection of its municipal supply, it has become necessary for the city to acquire all water and water rights with lands annexed to the city or from lands being initially provided with water service, or, if insufficient, to receive a monetary equivalent therefor. Direct flow mutual ditch company stock and interests in area reservoirs would provide water and water rights assisting the city in meeting and anticipating the present and future requirement for the protection of its municipal water supply system. It is deemed by the city council to be to the best interest of the city, its citizens and its future citizens to establish a policy of requiring, as a prerequisite to annexation or as a prerequisite to initiation of water service to their land, that petitioners requesting annexation of or initiation of water service to their land tender and be prepared to convey all water and water rights appurtenant to and historically used on or associated with the land, or, if not sufficient, pay a monetary equivalent therefor. 
(b)  Conveyance and transfer of water rights or cash payments in connection with requests for annexation or water service. In order to assure an adequate water supply for land to be annexed to and provided with water service by the city, all petitioners requesting annexation of land, or initiation of water service to land proposed for annexation, shall, at no cost to the city, as a prerequisite to receiving the approval of city council, be required, at the election of the city, to: 
(1)  Convey and transfer to the city: 
a.  All water and water rights, ditches and ditch rights, reservoirs and reservoir rights, wells and well rights and all other water rights or rights to use water appurtenant to, located on or used in connection with said land; and 
b.  All easements, rights of way, equipment or structures necessary for or associated with the diversion, storage, transmission and/or use of such water rights and rights to use water; or 
(2)  Pay to the city in cash an amount of money sufficient for the city to acquire, or to offset the city's previous acquisition of, at applicable fair market values at the time of the petition for annexation or water service, and to obtain necessary approvals for the city's use of, water rights or rights to use water which will provide an adequate water supply for the annexed land. 
The city's election of whether to accept water rights and rights to use water or cash payments shall be made as soon as possible after a request for annexation or water service is received by the city, and shall be included as a term of the annexation agreement. 
Adequate water supply for annexed areas: required approvals. If the city elects to require conveyance or transfer of water rights and rights to use water, any such rights shall provide an adequate water supply for the land to be annexed and provided with water service. Such water rights and rights to use water shall be deemed to be an adequate water supply only if they are able to supply at least 1.26 consumptive acre-feet of water on a firm annual yield basis for each acre of land to be annexed after all approvals necessary to insure legal and physical availability of the water for city uses have been finally obtained, including, but not limited to, any approvals required from ditch, reservoir or irrigation companies or districts, any approvals required from the water court or any other court or any administrative approvals. City uses shall include all municipal uses, irrigation, augmentation, exchange, replacement and substitution and any other uses deemed by the city to be in the interest of the city. If approval of a ditch, reservoir or irrigation company or district is, or may be, required to allow use of the water rights and rights to use water for city uses, the petitioner shall be responsible, at no cost to the city, for obtaining such approvals, or determinations that no approval is necessary, before the city will approve annexation of or water service to such land. All such approvals or determinations shall be presented by petitioner to the city in final written form sufficient to show the company's or district's approval of city use of the water to be conveyed or transferred and to allow the city to determine the amount of water which will be annually available for city uses. Subject to cash payments which may be required under this section (b), the city shall be responsible, at its cost, for obtaining approvals required of the water court or other court or administrative approvals needed to make the water available for city uses. 
Amount of cash payment. If the city elects to require a cash payment, any cash payments made to the city shall be sufficient for the city to: 
(1)  Acquire, at applicable fair market values at the time the petition for annexation or water service is made, water rights or rights to use water which provide an adequate water supply for the land to be annexed or served in the amount of at least 1.26 consumptive acre-feet of water on a firm annual yield basis for each acre of land to be annexed after all approvals described in this section (b) which are necessary to insure legal and physical availability of such water for city uses have been finally obtained; and/or 
(2)  Offset the city's previous acquisition of water rights or rights to use water which may be used by the city to provide an adequate water supply in the amount of at least 1.26 consumptive acre-feet of water on a firm annual yield basis for each acre of land to be annexed. 
In addition, such cash payment shall also be sufficient to allow the city to obtain all court, administrative, company, district or other approvals which may be necessary to use the water rights and rights to use water for city uses, or to offset the cost of previously obtained approvals of water rights or rights to use water which may be used to provide water to the annexed or served lands. The city shall determine the amount of said cash payment in connection with each annexation, provided that the amount of money to be paid shall be not less than $1,616.00 per acre of land to be annexed. 
Determination of adequate water supply. For planning purposes only, the firm consumptive amount of water which shall be deemed to be available annually for city uses from certain ditch and reservoir companies in the Sterling area will be as specified in the following table: 
Water right (ditch) Annual CU per share (ac-ft) City CU annual requirement per acre (ac-ft) Fractional share needed to fully supply one acre annually Number of acres supplied with one share Sterling No. 1 7.6 1.26 0.17 6 Farmers Pawnee 19.1 1.23 0.07 15.2 Springdale 2.6 1.26 0.48 2.1 Morgan Prewit CU per share after conveyance loss 9.35 1.23 0.13 7.4  
In connection with a specific request for annexation or water service, however, the city shall, in its sole discretion, determine whether any and all water tendered to the city will provide an adequate water supply for the land annexed. Based on the size of or projected water demand associated with a specific annexation request, or other relevant factors, the city may require the petitioner, as a term of the annexation agreement, to provide for the city's review an analysis, and all background information used to prepare the analysis, by a competent water rights engineering firm which projects the average and firm annual water requirements for the annexed area and the amount of water which will be available for city uses from water rights or rights to use water to be conveyed or transferred to the city. The petitioner shall pay any and all costs associated with the analysis and subsequent review by the city. 
City's options if tendered water rights do not provide an adequate supply. If, based on its review of the analysis, and such other information on which the city may choose to rely, the city determines that the amount of water tendered will supply less than 1.26 consumptive acre-feet of water annually per acre annexed for any reason, including, but not limited to, that adequate court, administrative, company or district approvals cannot be obtained, if the land proposed for annexation or water service is dry land with which no water rights or rights to use water are tendered to the city, or if there are material defects in the title to the water rights proposed to be conveyed or transferred, determined as set forth in this section (b), the city may, in its sole discretion, exercise any of the following options separately or in combination: 
(1)  The city may require the petitioner to furnish water rights or rights to use water sufficient on their own, or, if the city agrees, in combination with any water rights or rights to use water previously tendered, to supply for city uses not less than 1.26 consumptive acre-feet of water annually per acre annexed; 
(2)  The city may require the petitioner to make cash payments to the city on the basis and in an amount determined as set forth in this section (b) sufficient for the city to acquire and obtain approvals of, or offset its previous acquisition and approvals of, water rights or rights to use water which are adequate on their own, or, if the city agrees, in combination with any water rights or rights to use water previously tendered, to supply for city uses not less than 1.26 consumptive acre-feet of water annually per acre to be annexed; 
(3)  The city may, in its sole discretion, refuse the annexation or service request. 
All decisions regarding the choice and application of these options to any specific request for annexation or service shall be in the sole discretion of the city. 
Payment for change of water rights conveyed or transferred to city. In addition to any transfer and conveyance of water rights or rights to use water, whether in full or partial satisfaction of the requirements of this section (b), the petitioner shall also make a cash payment to the city to offset the city's cost of obtaining necessary court approvals. The amount of said payment shall be determined by the city for each annexation or water service request, but shall not be less than $300.00 for each acre-foot of water which may be available for city uses under the water rights or rights to use water after any final approvals required from ditch, reservoir or irrigation companies or districts have been obtained by the petitioner. 
Title to water rights to be conveyed or transferred to city. As part of the annexation agreement, the city may also require the petitioner to provide for the city's review a report, and all background information used to prepare the report, prepared by a competent attorney or other competent professional experienced in determining water right ownership which demonstrates that the petitioner is the owner of and vested with marketable title to the water rights or rights to use water which are proposed to be conveyed or transferred to the city. The petitioner shall pay any and all costs associated with the report and subsequent review by the city. If, based on its review of the report, or other information on which the city may choose to rely, the city, in its sole discretion, determines that there are material defects in the title to the water rights which will prevent conveyance or transfer of marketable title to the city, the city may request the petitioner to cure such defects. If, due to the existence of uncured title defects, the city elects not accept water rights or rights to use water in satisfaction of the petitioner's obligations under this ordinance, the city may, at its sole discretion, attempt to complete the annexation by the exercise any of the dedication or cash payments options described above in this section (b). 
Determination of water requirements in specified zoned areas. The annual consumptive use water requirements, the number of shares or fractional shares needed to supply such requirements and the number of acres which may be supplied with each water share which are set forth in the foregoing table shall apply to requests for annexation or water service in all areas to be annexed to the city except those areas to be zoned R-3, L-1 or H-1, for which water requirements are expected to differ from those in the table. In those zoning areas, the city shall require that an analysis by a competent water rights engineering firm be provided, along with all background information used to prepare the analysis, by the petitioner for the city's review that projects the average and firm annual water requirements of lands proposed for annexation or water service in those areas. The petitioner shall pay any and all costs associated with the analysis and subsequent review by the city. As set forth above in this section (b), the city may also require an analysis of the amount of water which will be available for city uses from water rights or rights to use water to be conveyed or transferred to the city as part of the annexation agreement. Based on its review of the analyses, and such other information on which the city may choose to rely, the city shall, in its sole discretion, determine the water requirements for such areas. Any water rights or rights to use water tendered to meet the water requirements for a development in R-3, L-1 or H-1, or any cash payments which supplement or are in lieu of the tender and conveyance or transfer of water rights, shall then be governed by and shall meet all conveyance and transfer or cash payment requirements of this section (b) which the city elects to apply. 
Schedule: requirements for completion of approvals. The city and the petitioner shall agree upon a schedule for completion of the requirements of this section (b) in the annexation agreement, which schedule may be extended in writing by the city manager or director of public works, on their own or at the request of the petitioner, if appropriate to accommodate changed or unanticipated circumstances. In no event, however, shall the city finally accept the conveyance or transfer of any water rights or rights to use water under this section (b) until all approvals required of any ditch, reservoir or irrigation companies or districts, all required court approvals and all required administrative approvals have been completed by the petitioner or the city, title to the water rights has been demonstrated to the city's satisfaction and the city has agreed to accept such water rights and rights to use water in full or partial satisfaction of the requirements of this section (b), provided that the city may agree to and require conveyance or transfer of such rights before company or district approvals are finally obtained if, in the judgment of the city manager or director of public works, doing so is necessary to enhance the city's ability to obtain court approvals of its right to use the water for city uses. Any cash payments which may be required under this section (b) shall be completed before the city will approve any request for annexation or water service. 
Requirements for conveyance and transfers of water rights. All conveyances or transfers of water rights or rights to use water to the city under this section (b) shall comply with all legal requirements applicable to such conveyances and transfers. It shall be the responsibility of the petitioner, at his cost, to obtain any authority to complete, and to complete, any necessary transfers of shares of ditch or reservoir companies on the records of such companies, to complete any assignments of shares or contract rights to use water to the city and to complete all other legal requirements applicable to the conveyance or transfer. All instruments of conveyance or transfer shall be recordable and in a form satisfactory to the city in its sole discretion. 
City council's final authority. The responsibility for all final elections and decisions under this section (b) shall be vested in the city council. Petitioners shall present written requests for annexation or water service to the city manager in a form acceptable to the city manager, and shall work with the city manager and other city staff to comply timely with the requirements of this section (b). 
(Code 1961, § 26-12; Ord. No. 15-2000, 4-25-00, eff. 5-5-00) 
Sec. 21-65. - Prerequisites for service to property outside city. 
    Prior to connection to the city's water system, each owner of property which is not within the corporate limits of the city shall: 
(1)  Begin and pursue to completion the annexation of the property to the city, if the property is eligible for immediate annexation. 
(2)  If the property is not eligible for immediate annexation: 
a.  Agree in writing to annex all of the property served with water by the city when the property becomes eligible for annexation and to sign any petitions and do all things which the property owner may do or must do under the requirements of the state constitution to effect the annexation. The agreement shall be made a covenant running with the land. 
b.  Furnish to the city, at no cost, the necessary easements and rights-of-way to provide water service to the property. 
c.  Agree in writing that no water pressures outside the city limits can be guaranteed and that any booster pump or system is to be installed and maintained at no cost to the city. The agreement shall be made a covenant running with the land. 
(Code 1961, § 26-10) 
Sec. 21-66. - Same-Public improvements requirements. 
(a)  Prior to receiving water service, the owner of a single residential property located outside the city limits and not presently eligible for annexation must comply with the following: 
(1)  Agree in writing to include the property in any special improvement district formed to provide water service, facilities, lines or related services in which the property is eligible to be included at such time as the eligibility occurs. The agreement is to be made a covenant running with the land. 
(2)  Agree in writing to include the property in any special improvement district formed to provide curb, gutter, paved streets, sidewalks, storm sewer, sanitary sewer and other public improvements and not to oppose the formation of the districts, and that the installation of the improvements will be provided at no cost to the city according to city specifications when the property has been annexed to the city. The agreement is to be made a covenant running with the land. 
(b)  Prior to receiving water service, the owner, subdivider or developer of a subdivision of two (2) or more lots located within the corporate limits of the city or which is eligible for immediate annexation must comply with the following: 
(1)  Install, at no cost to the city, all curbs, gutters, paved streets, sidewalks, storm sewers, sanitary sewers and other public improvements according to city specifications and in accordance with the requirements of chapter 18, pertaining to subdivisions. 
(2)  Install all water lines and taps per city specifications, at no cost to the city, with no repayment provisions. 
If it is not physically possible or practical, as determined in the sole discretion of the director of public works, to make the installations required at the time of first receiving water service, the owner shall agree in writing to install them as soon as the installation becomes possible. The agreement shall be made a covenant running with the land. 
(c)  Prior to receiving water service, the owners of property located outside the corporate limits of the city and not eligible for immediate annexation, in existing platted subdivisions which are wholly or partially developed and where more than one (1) owner is involved, shall be furnished water service only on a special district basis and must comply with the following: 
(1)  Satisfy all city subdivision regulations. 
(2)  Furnish to the city, at no cost, the necessary rights-of-way, dedicated streets and alleys for the installation of the water system. 
(3)  Install all the water lines and taps per city specifications at the district's expense with no repayment provisions. 
(4)  Comply with any then-existing requirements of the city for inspections of the work, including paying an inspector qualified and approved by the director of public works, if this condition is required by the director of public works. 
(5)  Agree in writing to include the property in any special improvement district which is formed to provide curb, gutter, paved streets, sidewalks, storm sewer, sanitary sewer and other public improvements and not to oppose the formation of the districts, and that the installation of the improvements will be provided at no cost to the city according to city specifications when the property has been annexed to the city. The agreement is to be made a covenant running with the land. 
(6)  Comply with Appendix A. Zoning of the City Code. 
(7)  Comply with all codes set forth in Chapters 5 and 7 of the City Code. 
(d)  Prior to receiving water service, the owner of property located in a newly developed and platted subdivision wholly owned by one (1) individual, a partnership, joint venture or corporation which is not eligible for immediate annexation shall comply with the requirements of subsections (c) (1) through (7) of this section, but will not be required to include the property in a special improvement district formed to provide water service, facilities, lines and other related services. 
(Ord. No. 24-2004, 9-28-04, eff. 10-8-04) 
Sec. 21-67. - Installations on annexed land to become city property. 
    Upon annexation of property by the city, all water installations covered by this article shall become the property of the city without any repayment therefor. No liability or obligation for the maintenance thereof or responsibility therefor by the city shall accrue until that time. 
(Code 1961, § 26-14) 
Sec. 21-68. - Disconnection from private systems. 
    Whenever the city is capable of providing water service to any property within the city limits, then, at such time and thereafter, no person shall provide water to any such property by any private water system or any other water system other than the water system made available by the city. Any private water system previously serving the property shall be physically disconnected from the residence, building or structure, and no private water may be piped to the residence, building or structure thereafter. Noncompliance with this requirement shall be a violation of this section. This physical disconnection must be accomplished by a complete separation of the line between the residence, building or structure and the private water source. No valving system between a private water source and the city's water system shall be allowed. The installation, operation or maintenance of such a connection or valving system shall be a violation of this section. 
(Code 1961, § 26-2) 
Sec. 21-69. - Application for service. 
    Any person desiring water service from the city's water system or who is required to be connected to the city's water system by section 21-68 or under other applicable law shall make application to the director of public works as provided in article II of this chapter, as a part of the utility service application and agreement. 
(Code 1961, § 26-3; Ord. No. 7-1989, § 26-3, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89; Ord. No. 23-1989, § 26-3, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 21-70. - Number of taps required. 
(a)  Each single-family residence shall have a separate tap as a minimum. 
(b)  Multiple-family residences shall have at least one (1) separate tap for each building. 
(c)  Property zoned for commercial or industrial use may use a single tap for each lot regardless of the number of buildings, provided that if the lot is subdivided or any building without its own water tap is sold separately, then the owner of the building without a water tap must apply for a separate tap and pay the plant investment fee. 
(Code 1961, § 26-5) 
Sec. 21-71. - Superintendent to supervise connections, disconnections. 
    The water superintendent shall supervise the connection of any water service to or disconnection of any water service from the city's water supply. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to turn on, cause to be turned on or connected, turn off, or cause to be turned off or disconnected any water service from the mains of the city water supply at any service tap or connection. Any person who violates this section may additionally lose any contractor's license issued by the city, through the cancellation of the license by the director of finance or by an order of the municipal court, after a conviction for a violation of this section. 
(Code 1961, § 26-15) 
Secs. 21-72-21-79. - Reserved. 
Sec. 21-80. - Water supply emergencies. 
    The city council may, should conditions merit, declare a water emergency. In the event a water emergency is declared by city council, council shall direct staff to prepare a plan to alleviate said emergency, which shall require council approval. Any plan, after approved by council and while in effect, may be amended to meet changing circumstances. Any amendment shall require council approval. Any such emergency plan, or its amendment, as adopted by council, shall remain in effect until council declares an end to the water emergency. Any violation of any of the provisions of an emergency water plan shall be a violation committed pursuant to section 21-63 of the Code, and punishable pursuant to section 1-15 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 8-2003, 4-22-03, eff. 5-2-03) 
Secs. 21-81-21-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 21-91. - Water enterprise fund. 
    An existing water fund shall be designated as a water enterprise fund. Revenues from all rates, charges, fees and the like set forth in this article, and other related appropriate revenues, shall be deposited in the water enterprise fund. The water enterprise fund shall be self-sufficient, and the various charges, rates and fees shall be set by city council resolution to generate funds to offset the cost of operation of the city's water system, the cost of capital improvements to the system that are needed or required, and reserves as determined necessary to cover contingencies and capital improvements of such system. The city council shall make an annual review of the water enterprise fund, taking into account the self-sufficiency purpose of the fund, so that the fund does not run a deficit at any time. 
(Ord. No. 7-1989, § 26-16, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89) 
Cross reference- Funds, § 19-201 et seq. 
Sec. 21-92. - Payment of charges. 
    All water service charges and other charges set by the city council pursuant to this article shall be considered utility charges. All utility charges established pursuant to this article shall be billed pursuant to the procedure in article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1961, § 26-7; Ord. No. 7-1989, § 26-7, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89; Ord. No. 23-1989, § 26-7, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Cross reference- Finance, § 19-181 et seq. 
Sec. 21-93. - Plant investment fee. 
    Prior to connection to the city's water system, at the time a water tap is applied for, and at the time of each new construction, if an increased demand is placed on the city's system by new building, each property to be connected to the city's water system shall be assessed and the owner shall pay a plant investment fee representing that property's share of the capital expense of providing the pumping facilities and transmission lines of the city. The plant investment fee shall be set by city council resolution and shall be reviewed annually. The city council may adjust the plant investment fee following the review, by resolution. The owner shall also pay all other charges, fees and assessments provided for in this article and by general law relating to water usage at the location of the property for which service is requested. 
(Code 1961, § 26-9; Ord. No. 7-1989, § 26-9, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89) 
Sec. 21-94. - Tapping fee. 
    Any person desiring water service from the city shall pay a tapping fee for the installation of a water tap and meter. The fee shall be set by city council resolution and reviewed annually. The city council may make adjustments to the fee following the review, by resolution. 
(Code 1961, § 26-4; Ord. No. 7-1989, § 26-4, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89) 
Sec. 21-95. - Rates generally. 
(a)  Every person having an account with the city for water service supplied by the city and received through a metered water tap shall pay for the water at the rate as set by the city council by resolution. The rate shall be reviewed annually and the city council may make adjustments to the rate following review, by resolution. 
(b)  There shall be a minimum monthly charge for each and every metered water tap regardless of the amount of water actually received. This minimum monthly charge shall be set by city council resolution and shall be reviewed annually. The city council may make adjustments to this charge following the review, by resolution. All water charges shall be computed, charged and paid for to the nearest one thousand (1,000) gallons actually received at the water tap. 
(Code 1961, § 26-6; Ord. No. 7-1989, § 26-6, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89) 
Sec. 21-96. - Charge for restoring water service. 
    A service charge shall be charged for restoring any water service to any property. The service charge shall be set by city council resolution and reviewed annually. Adjustments may be made in the charge following the review, by city council resolution. No service charge will be required when the water is turned off for the convenience of the city or other utility. No service charge shall be charged for initial service. 
(Code 1961, § 26-8; Ord. No. 7-1989, § 26-8, 9-26-89, eff. 9-26-89; Ord. No. 23-1989, § 26-8, 12-27-89, eff. 1-1-90) 
Sec. 21-97. - Rates for service outside city. 
    The city may, at its sole discretion, extend the use of its water system beyond the corporate limits of the city. In such cases, the rates for such service shall be set by city council resolution and shall be reviewed annually thereafter. The city council may make adjustments to these rates following review, by resolution. 
(Code 1961, § 26-6; Ord. No. 7-1989, § 26-6, 9-26-89, eff. 9-29-89) 
Secs. 21-98-21-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEWER SYSTEM[3] 
Footnotes:

IV consisted of Div. 1, §§ 21-116-21-131, Div. 2, §§ 21-151-21-165, Div. 3, §§ 21-181-21-186, and Div. 4, §§ 21-206-21-223, all of which pertained to the sewer system and derived from §§ 23-1-23-64 of the 1961 Code; §§ 23-1, 23-17, 23-23, 23-28, 23-29, 23-34, and 23-62-23-65 of Ord. DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-116. - Definitions. 
    In addition to definitions and abbreviations in section 21-202, the following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called the house connection. 
    City means the City of Sterling. 
    Director means the director of public works for the city, who heads the department of public works under article 8 of the Charter, or his or her designated representative. 
    Domestic sewage means wastewater from residential sources including, but not limited to, wastewater from kitchen, bath, and laundry facilities; or wastewater from the personal sanitary conveniences (toilets, showers, bathtubs, fountains, noncommercial sinks and similar structures) of commercial, industrial or institutional buildings, provided that the wastewater exhibits characteristics that are similar to those of wastewater from normal residential activities and not otherwise regulated by an applicable categorical pretreatment standard. 
    Easement means an acquired legal right held by the city for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    Existing platted subdivision means a subdivision, the plat of which has been properly recorded in the real estate records of the clerk and recorder of the county in conformity with the city ordinances and state statutes in effect at the time of filing. 
    Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet, including storm sewers, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Person is any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, society, corporation, group, government, governmental agency or other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. The definition includes all federal, state and local government entities. 
    Public sewer means a sanitary sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public utility. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions together with minor quantities of groundwater, stormwater and surface water that are not admitted intentionally. This definition shall also include, but not be limited to, the terms public sewer, sewer system, sewer and collection line. 
    Sanitary sewer service means a customer's connection to and use of the city's wastewater facilities for disposal of waste. 
    Sewage means human excrement and gray water (household showers, dishwashing operations, etc.). 
    Sewer plant investment fee means a pro rata investment in the city's wastewater facilities. 
    Single residential property means a lot, tract or parcel of land which is held in separate ownership from adjoining lots, parcels or tracts and which is designed, zoned and used for residential purposes. 
    Storm sewer or storm drain shall mean every pipe, culvert, flume, ditch, gutter, storm sewer, cistern, tank, drain, lake, pond, stream, ravine, gully or other facility or natural feature, that contains, holds, transports, diverts, channels, impounds, or drains water, into which any naturally occurring stormwater runoff within the city may seep, percolate or flow; and every street, sidewalk, alley, gutter, roof, parking lot, yard, field, driveway, patio and other surface within the city across which any naturally occurring stormwater runoff may seep, percolate or flow. 
    Stormwater means any surface flow, runoff, and drainage consisting entirely of water from any form of natural precipitation and resulting from such precipitation, including snowmelt. 
    Subdivision means two (2) or more contiguous platted lots or tracts lawfully subdivided pursuant to the applicable ordinances of the city and statutes of the state. 
    Tapping charge means a fee to pay for labor and materials needed to tap into the city's wastewater facilities to serve a customer. 
    User means any person using or connected to the city's POTW.
